game.name: Fatal Fury 2 / Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-naru Tatakai (NGM-047 ~ NGH-047)
game.description: Fatal Fury 2 / Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-naru Tatakai (NGM-047 ~ NGH-047)
game.title_clean: Fatal Fury 2 / Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-naru Tatakai
game.plot: 餓狼伝説2 新たなる闘い (c) 1992 SNK Corp.[CR](Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai)[CR]The lone wolves are back once again and they will battle the world's strongest fighters. However a mysterious & powerful new enemy is looking for them, the ones who defeated Geese Howard.[CR]Can the lone wolves face this new threat and come out victorious?[CR]Features backgrounds with 2 different background planes, improved control & some very nice music! :)[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-047[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player.[CR][Joystick] 8-way, => [A] Quick Punch [B] Quick Kick [C] Strong Punch [D] Strong Kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Garou Densetsu 2 was released in December 1992 in Japan.[CR]The title of the translates from Japanese as 'Legend of Hungry Wolf 2 - The New Battle'.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as 'Fatal Fury 2'. According to the USA flyer, the name of the game is 'Fatal Fury 2 - The Sultan of Slugs Battle Royale'.[CR]Things that changed in this sequel :[CR]* This game allows you to switch between the background & foreground planes at will (in the first game, you could only switch planes if the CPU was on a different battle plane!).[CR]* The game ditches the previous game's 3 button setup (punch, kick & throw) in favor of a new 4 button setup (light & heavy punches & kicks). This is apparently one of the very first Neo-Geo fighters to use this now common button setup.[CR]* This game introduces the use of Desperation Moves (highly damaging techniques that can only be used when the life-bar is flashing red). This game as well as "Art of Fighting" were the first fighting games to introduce these moves.[CR]* Newcomers in the game are : Mai Shiranui, Cheng Sinzan, Kim Kaphwan, Jubei Yamada, Big Bear (aka Raiden), Axel Hawk, Lawrence Blood & Wolfgang Krauser. Richard Meyer, Michael Max, Tung Fu Rue, Duck King, Hwa Jai & Geese Howard were left out! (although some of them make some cameos during some of the game's cut-scenes!).[CR]Just as the first game introduced the famed Terry Bogard, this game features SNK's most popular fighter lady : Mai Shiranui! :). Mai appears in "Quiz King of Fighters" as selectable character.[CR]The Hungry Wolf is a reference to Terry Bogard, the main character in Fatal Fury. Terry, Andy and Joe (and to a lesser extent, Mai and Mary) are referred to as the Lone Wolves.[CR]Keeping the tradition of the first game, an animated movie based on this game was released in Japan featuring character designs by Masami Ohbari. The movie was also released in the USA by Viz Video, a division of Viz Comics. After the second Fatal Fury movie was released, a third movie followed (which predated "Fatal Fury 3 - Road to the Final Victory"). It follows the adventures of the Lonely Wolves (Terry, Andy, Joe and Mai) as they attempt to prevent a power-hungry man from claiming all the parts of the legendary Armor of Mars.[CR]When a player wins a match in a single player game, the post match screen shows people watching the tournament inside the Pao Pao Cafe from the first game, "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters".[CR]Pony Canyon released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Garou Densetsu 2 - PCCB-00111) on 19/02/1993.[CR]Reviews:[CR][FR] March 1993 - Consoles + No. 18: 97/100 (AES version)[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* You can only see any character's ending if you beat the game with a single credit used (no continues or 2-Player matches are allowed)[CR]* Just like the first game, it's possible to use the strategy of dashing at your opponents just as they're getting up in order to damage them repeatedly.[CR]* Billy Kane, Axel Hawk and Lawrence Blood all have stages that use a single plane, with the 'second' plane having objects on it that can injure players if they're knocked against them (all three of these bosses have ways of throwing their opponents into the background). You can knock the bosses into the background too by standing close to them while they're dazed and then hitting them with a good hard kick or punch.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Garou Densetsu - Shukumei no Tatakai [Model NGM-033] (1991, MVS)[CR]2. Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai [Model NGM-047] (1992, MVS)[CR]3. Garou Densetsu Special [Model NGM-058] (1993, MVS)[CR]4. Garou Densetsu 3 - Harukanaru Tatakai [Model NGM-069] (1995, MVS)[CR]5. Real Bout Garou Densetsu [Model NGM-095] (1995, MVS)[CR]6. Real Bout Garou Densetsu Special [Model NGM-223] (1997, MVS)[CR]7. Real Bout Garou Densetsu 2 - The Newcomers [Model NGM-240] (199, MVS8)[CR]8. Fatal Fury Wild Ambition (1999, ARC)[CR]9. Garou - Mark of the Wolves [Model NGM-253] (1999, MVS)[CR]10. Fatal Fury First Contact [Model NEOP00111] (1999, NGPC)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer : Eikichi Kawasaki[CR]Planners : Deru-Deru, Tsukamichi-2, Chinta[CR]Object Designers : Higashi Pon (Higashipon Mark3), Tony Oki, Tsuzakingyo (Tsuzakingyo 2), Lionheart, U.G, Ryouji-Sei, Soe Soe (Super Soe Soe), Heitarou, Terarin, Horipu (Horigen. Pu-Ta)[CR]Back Scroll Designers : Moriyan, Somatreeno, Oba Obata, Shibatarian, Uri Midopon, A-Chang[CR]Character Back Up : Manuke, Teizo Muta 92, Kama Kama, Takeshi Kimura, Man, Take. P, Albinome, Pinkey. TBC440[CR]Programmers : Yamatan (Yamatan-2' Turbo), Speaker. R[CR]Sound : Toshio Shimizm (Shimizm), Yoko, Jojoha Kitapy, YLF. Communicate, Paciorek, Masahiko Hataya (Papaya)[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Terry Bogard : Satoshi Hashimoto[CR]Andy Bogard : Jun Hashimoto[CR]Joe Higashi : Katsuhisa Namase[CR]Mai Shiranui : Akoya Sogi[CR]Big Bear : Dango Takeda[CR]Cheng Sinzan : Jun Hashimoto[CR]Laurence Blood : Katsuhisa Namase[CR]Axel Hawk : Michael Beard[CR]Billy Kane : Katsuhisa Namase[CR]Wolfgang Krauser : Michael Beard[CR]Special Thanks : Kazuya Hirata, Prince Deguchi, Kura, Shinchan, Data Tada, Oh!Butch (Oh! Buchii), Carry, Kenchan, Miyagami, Satochan, Sanpo, Iwata Kun, Hiroshi Matsumoto (Finish Hiroshi), Akiko Tsuruta, Mie Kurita, Megumi Moriyama, 1st Operation Staff[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (Mar.5, 1993; "Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai [Model NGH-047]")[CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (Nov.26, 1993; "Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai [Model SHVC-DJ]")[CR]NEC PC-Engine CD [JP] (Mar.12, 1994; "Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai [Model HCD4060]")[CR]Nintendo Super NES [US] (Apr. 1994; "Fatal Fury 2 [Model SNS-DJ]")[CR]Nintendo Super NES [EU] (1994; "Fatal Fury 2 [Model SNSP-DJ]")[CR]Sega Mega Drive [JP] (June 24, 1994; "Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai [Model T-146023]")[CR]Sega Genesis [US] (1994; "Fatal Fury 2")[CR]Nintendo Game Boy [JP] (July 29, 1994; "Nettou Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai [Model DMG-X3J]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [JP] (Sep.9, 1994; "Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai [Model NGCD-047]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (July 20, 2006; "Garou Densetsu Battle Archives 1 [NeoGeo Online Collection Vol.5] [Model SLPS-25664]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (Aug.2007, "Fatal Fury Battle Archives Volume 1")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (July 2008, "Fatal Fury Battle Archives Volume 1")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (May 29, 2008; "Garou Densetsu Battle Archives 1 [NeoGeo Online Collection The Best] [Model SLPS-25863]")[CR]* Computers :[CR]Sharp X68000 [JP] (Dec. 23, 1993, "Garou Densetsu 2 [Model MGX-5002]")[CR]

game.name: Fatal Fury 3 - Road to the Final Victory / Garou Densetsu 3 - Haruka-naru Tatakai (NGM-069 ~ NGH-069)
game.description: Fatal Fury 3 - Road to the Final Victory / Garou Densetsu 3 - Haruka-naru Tatakai (NGM-069 ~ NGH-069)
game.title_clean: Fatal Fury 3 - Road to the Final Victory / Garou Densetsu 3 - Haruka-naru Tatakai
game.plot: 餓狼伝説3 遥かなる闘い (c) 1995 SNK [Shin Nihon Kikaku].[CR](Garou Densetsu 3 - Harukanaru Tatakai)[CR]During a trip to Southtown to attend the inauguration of a new branch of Pao Pao Cafe by former street fighter Richard Meyer, the lone wolves (Terry Bogard, Andy Bogard, Joe Higashi & Mai Shiranui) are unwillingly caught in the middle of a desperate search for the Shiranui Scrolls and the mysterious fighters that are after them! The game features a new graphic style, 2 different background planes to fight, a grade system that shows how well you perform in battle, lots of hidden moves & combos, as well as multiple endings based on your performance. The answers shall only be uncovered by a long & fierce battle, are you up to it?[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID: NGM-069[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons Per Player.[CR][Joystick] 8-way [A] Quick Punch [B] Quick Kick [C] Power Punch [D] Power Kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Garou Densetsu 3 was released in March 1995 in Japan.[CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Legend of Hungry Wolf 3 - The Distant Battle'.[CR]Garou Densetsu 3 overtly refers to itself by its overseas name of 'Fatal Fury 3' throughout the game.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as 'Fatal Fury 3 - Road to the Final Victory'.[CR]Things that changed in this particular game:[CR]* The game introduces a deeper plane change system which proved to be somewhat clunky & difficult to use due to the tricky commands used to move between planes.[CR]* Chain combos are introduced to add even more depth to each character's fighting style. [CR]* Throws are harder to use since these are slow and throw-miss animations were added.[CR]* Newcomers in the game are Bob Wilson, Blue Mary, Franco Bash, Hon Fu, Sokaku Mochizuki, Ryuji Yamazaki, Jin Chonshu & Jin Chonrei.[CR]Hon Fu's goofy martial artist routine & easygoing personality make him SNK's hilarious homage to Jackie Chan. Definitely not a Bruce Lee clone! :)[CR]Kyo Kusanagi & Sie Kensou make a cameo in Pao Pao Cafe![CR]Pony Canyon released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Garou Densetsu 3 - PCCB-00179) on April 21, 1995.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]Reach and beat Jin Chonshu with a fighting grade above "A" and you'll fight a hidden last boss, her brother, Jin Chonrei.[CR]One of the coolest things of this game is the fact that you can alter some backgrounds objects by slamming opponents against them. For example, you can knock away the training dummy in Joe's stage if you send an opponent flying towards it. Experiment on various stages to find more surprises![CR]Note : If the game is set on the USA, ASIA or EUROPE bios, the game will reset after defeating Jin Chonrei and you won't get to see the ending, however if the game is set on the JAPAN bios it will work just fine![CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Garou Densetsu - Shukumei no Tatakai [Model NGM-033] (1991, MVS)[CR]2. Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai [Model NGM-047] (1992, MVS)[CR]3. Garou Densetsu Special [Model NGM-058] (1993, MVS)[CR]4. Garou Densetsu 3 - Harukanaru Tatakai [Model NGM-069] (1995, MVS)[CR]5. Real Bout Garou Densetsu [Model NGM-095] (1995, MVS)[CR]6. Real Bout Garou Densetsu Special [Model NGM-223] (1997, MVS)[CR]7. Real Bout Garou Densetsu 2 - The Newcomers [Model NGM-240] (199, MVS8)[CR]8. Fatal Fury Wild Ambition (1999, ARC)[CR]9. Garou - Mark of the Wolves [Model NGM-253] (1999, MVS)[CR]10. Fatal Fury First Contact [Model NEOP00111] (1999, NGPC)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Terry Bogard : Satoshi Hashimoto[CR]Andy Bogard : Keiichi Nanba[CR]Joe Higashi : Nobuyuki Hiyama[CR]Mai Shiranui : Akoya Sogi[CR]Geese Howard : Kong Kuwata[CR]Sokaku Mochizuki, Ryuji Yamazaki : Koji Ishii[CR]Bob Wilson, Hon-Fu : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Blue Mary : Harumi Ikoma[CR]Franco Bash : B. J. game.name: Football Frenzy (NGM-034 ~ NGH-034)
game.plot: Football Frenzy (c) 1992 SNK [Shin Nihon Kikaku].[CR]A football game where 8 teams (10 in all) take part in a single-elimination tournament to decide who is the best.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID: NGM-034[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 Players - 4 Buttons Per Player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Football Frenzy was released on January 31, 1992.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer : Eikichi Kawasaki[CR]Chief Designer : Tomomi (Tomomi. M)[CR]Designers : Mina Kawai, Toshiaki Joe, Tick, Nishi Futatsu (Futatsu!!!), Tami Sugiura[CR]Main Programmer : Makoto[CR]Programmers : Data Tada, Masami Tanaka[CR]Sound : Tina Terko, Tate Norio, Jojoha Kitapy[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (February 21, 1992; "Football Frenzy [Model NGH-034]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [US] (February 21, 1992; "Football Frenzy [Model NGH-034]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [JP] (September 9, 1994; "Football Frenzy [Model NGCD-034]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [US] (September 9, 1994; "Football Frenzy [Model NGCD-034E]")[CR]

game.name: Fight Fever (set 1)
game.plot: Fight Fever (c) 1994 Viccom.[CR]8 initially selectable characters face off to become the Tae Kwon Do master! After defeating the absolutely WACKY Master Taekuk, he becomes selectable as well to face off against end boss Karate Kenji.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0060[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player.[CR][JOYSTICK] 8-way [A] Light punch [B] Light kick [C] Heavy punch [D] Heavy kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Fight Fever was released in July 1994.[CR]This game is also known in Korea as "Wang Joong Wang" (translated from Korean as 'King of the Kings').[CR]Fight Fever is Viccom's only game developed and released for the SNK Neo-Geo MVS hardware (but was not released on the Neo-Geo AES home console).[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]The Korean titlescreen has a Korean flag in the background instead of flames.[CR]

game.name: Battle Flip Shot
game.plot: Battle Flip Shot (c) 1998 Visco Corp.[CR]A modern "Pong"-like game with selectable characters.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0247[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player.[CR][JOYSTICK] 8-way [A] Special attack [B] Slide [C] Provoke[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Battle Flip Shot was released in December 1998.[CR]This game runs on the Neo-Geo MVS and was not released on the Neo-Geo AES home console.[CR]The game was in location test two months (10/1998) before its release.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Battle Flip Shot (1998)[CR]2. Bang Bead (2001)[CR]

game.name: Galaxy Fight - Universal Warriors
game.plot: Galaxy Fight - Universal Warriors (c) 1995 Sunsoft.[CR]Fighting game with 8 selectable characters. Each stage is infinite in length and therefore allows lots of running attacks.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0078[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player.[CR]=> [Joystick] 8-way, [A] Subdued attack [B] Medium attack [C] Strong attack [D] Taunt opponent[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in January 1995.[CR]Galaxy Fight is Sunsoft's first game for the Neo-Geo MVS.[CR]The bonus round character 'Bonus-Kun' is a homage to "Street Fighter"'s Ryu character. He also appears as the bonus character in Sunsoft's other Neo Geo fighting game, "Waku Waku 7".[CR]Reviews:[CR][FR] April 1995, Consoles + N.42: 81/100 (Neo-Geo version)[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]Beat the game without losing a round (you can lose continues, but not rounds) to fight a hidden boss and get the staff roll after your character's ending. If you beat this hidden boss, you'll get a group shot of all your characters.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Galaxy Programmers : Yuichi Ueda, Shigetaka Inaba[CR]Graphic Designers : Toshihiko Narita, Murakiti, Atsuki Matsui, Kouki Kita, Masashi Kazikawa, Yasuhide Maeda, Nobuhide Suzuki, Kazuhiro Watabe, Eiji Koyama, Ryuichi Kunisue, Takeshi Goya, Daisuke Fukuda[CR]Tool Programmer : Hirokatsu Fujii[CR]Sound Programmers : Kazuo Nii, Noriaki Urata[CR]Music Composers : Masato Araikawa, Takayuki Sasaki[CR]Musicians : Jun Kojime, Masato Araikawa[CR]Music Coordinators : Atsushi Mihiro, Shoji Yogo[CR]Voice Actors : Kazunori Hotta, Takakazu Tukamoto, Shinsuke Aoki, Naoto Sugisaka, Chiaki Kato, Tajuro, John Gibson[CR]Director : Yuichi Ueda[CR]Special Thanks : Akihiro Asada, Kazuyuki Watanabe, Kazuyo Uemura, Naomi Sakaguchi, Hiroshi Ito, Megumi Masuko[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (November 22, 1995) [Model T-1510G][CR]Sega Saturn [US] (July 3, 1996) [Model T-1504H][CR]Sega Saturn [EU] (1995) [Model T-1504H-50][CR]SNK Neo Geo [JP] (February 25, 1995) [Model SUH-078][CR]SNK Neo Geo [US] (February 25, 1995) [Model SUH-078][CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [JP] (April 21, 1995) [Model NGCD-078][CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [US] (April 21, 1995) [Model NGCD-078E][CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (May 3, 1996) [Model SLPS-00138][CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (April 1996) [Model SLES-00197][CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (March 29, 2007; "PS1 Classics")[CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (December 14, 2010; "PS1 Classics")[CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (January 11, 2012; "PS1 Classics") [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (June 26, 2008; "Sunsoft Collection [Model SLPS-25849]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (June 18, 2009; "Sunsoft Collection [NeoGeo Online Collection The Best] [Model SLPS-25936]")[CR]Nintendo Wii [JP] (March 23, 2010, "Virtual Console")[CR]

game.name: Ganryu / Musashi Ganryuki
game.plot: 武蔵厳流記 (c) 1999 Visco.(Musashi Ganryuki)[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0252[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player (3 usables)[CR][JOYSTICK] 8-way [A] Sword attack, [B] Jump, [C] Chain attack[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Musashi Ganryu Tale'.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as 'Ganryu'.[CR]This game runs on the Neo-Geo MVS but was not released on the Neo-Geo AES home console.[CR]On April 14th, 1612, Musashi defeated the famous - and some think superior - fencer Sasaki Ganryu Kojiro using a simple wooden sword which he carved from a boat oar on the way to the duel. Musashi had an opportunity to see Kojiro's sword sometime before the duel and knew of it's great length. Musashi carved the wooden sword to be of greater length. When Musashi arrived on the beach for the duel, he kept the wooden sword hidden behind him until the duel began. He jumped over a low strike of Kojiro, reaching about a meter off the ground and came down hard on Kojiro's head with his heavy wooden sword. Kojiro lay dying on the sand and Musashi left in a hurry without killing him. Some of Musashi's critics call him a coward for not killing him, but Musashi had proved his point as the killing of Kojiro was not the goal - defeating him was. This is why the Kojiro character in Musashi Ganryuki has a huge gash on his forehead. The storyline of Musashi Ganryuki is that Kojiro has come back from the dead to try and kill Musashi.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]Here are the statistics for the two characters :[CR]Musashi : Power 4 - Dexterity 2 - Vitality 4[CR]Suzume : Power 2 - Dexterity 5 - Vitality 3[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer : Ume.W[CR]Programmers : S. Kawakatsu[CR]Sound : Yasuko Reeb[CR]Graphic designers : Hanage, R.T, M.K, Mi, T. Nakahata, F. Onishi, T. Nakazawa, Mo, Sadaijin[CR]

game.name: Garou - Mark of the Wolves (NGM-2530)
game.plot: Garou - Mark of the Wolves (c) 1999 SNK.[CR]The 9th 'Fatal Fury' episode brings us 12 characters and foregoes the plane-switching style of its predecessors in favour of standard single-plane battles. One of the last games produced by the original SNK.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-253[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player.[CR][JOYSTICK] 8-way [A] Swift punch [B] Swift kick [C] Pummeler punch [D] Colossal kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in November 1999.[CR]'Garou' translates from Japanese as 'Hungry Wolf'. 'Mark of the Wolves' is a reference to the legacy left behind by Terry to a new generation of fighters - specifically, Rock Howard. This can also refer to the legacy left by other characters from the previous Fatal Fury & Art of Fighting games. Kim Dong Hwan & Kim Jae Hoon are sons of Tae-Kwon Do fighter Kim Kaphwan. Khushmood Butt is a master of Kyokugenryu Karate, the same martial used by Ryo Sakazaki from Art of Fighting. Hokutomaru uses Shiranui-style Ninjitsu as his fighting style, this is the same ninja arts that Mai Shiranui uses, however Hokutomaru was trained by Andy Bogard.[CR]Garou pushes the capabilities of the Neo-Geo MVS hardware to its limit, giving some of the best-looking graphics to date. Some critics saying that there is life after all in the Neo-Geo hardware, which was past its prime when the game was released.[CR]Hokutomaru's stage has quite a few references to the rest of the "Fatal Fury" series. To the extreme left of the stage is a billboard with a picture of the old style Terry Bogard. A portrait of Geese Howard and his lieutenants can be seen on another billboard (this is the same picture that is seen in the flyer for Real Bout Fatal Fury). There is also a picture of Andy Bogard and Mai Shiranui holding hands posing as a bank advertisement right above another picture of Alfred.[CR]The sign that Khushnood Butt shows off in his victory pose is a Kyokugen Karate dojo sign.[CR]The Rock Howard music stage contains a part of Robert Miles' seminal trance tune Children.[CR]Rock Howard is the son of the notorious crime-lord Geese Howard, the boss of previous Fatal Fury games. Rock was trained to fight by Terry Bogard and has incorporated moves from Terry and Geese's styles into his own fighting style. Rock is also related to Garou's main boss of the game: Kain R. Heinlein. Geese Howard married Marie Heinlein, whom is the sister of Kain. So, we can assume that Kain is Rock's uncle.[CR]The word 'Tizoc' (The Griffon Mask's Japanese name) means 'sick leg', or 'lame leg'. It was the name of an ancient Mexican tlatoani, or leader, who ruled from 1481 until 1486, when he was poisoned by Aztec aristocrats.[CR]If a double KO occurs, a round is won by each fighter, which can end a battle on this quite unsatisfying note. Moreover in this case, the player has no fighting level, neither displayed on the screen nor counted for the points.[CR]Soundtracks release:[CR][JP] Jan. 21, 2000; Garou - Mark of the Wolves [SCDC-00006] Scitron[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]The prototype version has a white background at the title screen instead a blue background on the final version. It has also a graphic bug on the Terry Bogard stage during the second round at the extreme right.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Random Fighter : Hold Start and press a Punch or Kick button at the character selection screen.[CR]* Play as Grant : At the character select screen, highlight Dong Hwan, hold Start and press Up(x2) Down(x2), Up, Down.[CR]* Play as Kain R. Heinlein : At the character select screen, highlight Jae Hoon, hold Start and press Down(x2), Up(x2), Down, Up.[CR]* Play against Kain R. Heinlein : To reach Kain, you must finish the first 7 matches with an average fighting level of AAA. Your best bet would be to avoid losing any rounds throughout the preliminary 7 stages, especially Grant. If you meet this condition after defeating Grant, you'll get a cutscene featuring Kain R. Heinlein. Beat Kain to reveal your characters' true ending.[CR]* Alternate Costume Colors : Each character has 4 colors, corresponding to each button.[CR]* Secret Taunts : After defeating your opponent, hold Left or Right and tap Start to use an hidden taunt. Every character has two secret taunts (these can ONLY be used after defeating an opponent and before your character goes into his/her winning pose). Some of them, such as Hotaru's and Hokutomaru's are really cool! :)[CR]Taunts in the game can affect the background stages in many ways. For example, by using a taunt during a fight in Hotaru's stage (Philanthropy Belfry) you can make the bells in the background move. Most stages have hidden animations that can only be seen by this trick so try it! :)[CR]* Survival Mode : Insert a coin, hold A+B+C+D and press Start. You will then play a Survival Mode (quite hard one too).[CR]* Rock's Win-pose : Rock will have a special win-pose when he finishes the opponent with a Shine Knuckle and a different one when he finishes the opponent with either a Raging Storm or the Deadly Rave Neo.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Garou Densetsu - Shukumei no Tatakai [Model NGM-033] (1991, MVS)[CR]2. Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai [Model NGM-047] (1992, MVS)[CR]3. Garou Densetsu Special [Model NGM-058] (1993, MVS)[CR]4. Garou Densetsu 3 - Harukanaru Tatakai [Model NGM-069] (1995, MVS)[CR]5. Real Bout Garou Densetsu [Model NGM-095] (1995, MVS)[CR]6. Real Bout Garou Densetsu Special [Model NGM-223] (1997, MVS)[CR]7. Real Bout Garou Densetsu 2 - The Newcomers [Model NGM-240] (199, MVS8)[CR]8. Fatal Fury Wild Ambition (1999, ARC)[CR]9. Garou - Mark of the Wolves [Model NGM-253] (1999, MVS)[CR]10. Fatal Fury First Contact [Model NEOP00111] (1999, NGPC)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Exective producer : H. Matsumoto[CR]Producers : S. Itoh, T. Tsukamoto[CR]Planners : Kim-Ken, Y. Oda, Goory, I. Higemura, Yucky[CR]Foreground designers : Soe Soe (SoeSoe.F), Heitarou, Rolly.R, N. Kuroki, Futatsu.N, G. Ishidamanf, Terarin, Itokatsu, S. Sasada, Eimotsu, Yuko, D-Mtl'Uchide, K. Naoe, Gi Pinoko, Yuko.K, T. Ishikawa[CR]Background designers : M. Hirano, D. Takagi, E. Tsutsui, Tomo, Sakura-E, R. Nariai, Shimidi, Kumiko.M, C. Zanami[CR]Special effects : Tashiboo, Masami Tanaka[CR]Event art designers : Kaoruru, M. Hirano, C. Zanami, A. Yamada[CR]New staff : Kohji, Z. Kadoma, Manbu, Zacky[CR]Programmers : Bo-Fukunaga, Dan-Abe, Rotten Air[CR]Sound : Ackey, Yassun, Hori-Hori, Okan, Q-Jirou[CR]Title designer : Nao-Q[CR]Illustrator : Tonko, Arita/Ymt[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Terry Bogard : Satoshi Hashimoto[CR]Rock Howard : Eiji Takemoto[CR]Kim Dong Hwan : Jun Hashimoto[CR]Kim Jae Hoon : Hiroki Asakawa[CR]Hotaru Futaba : Yuki Horie[CR]Gato : Koji Ishii[CR]B. Jenet : Rei Saito[CR]Khushmood Butt (Marco Rodriguez in Japanese version) : Hikaru Hanada[CR]Hokutomaru : Junko Takeuchi[CR]Freeman : Eiji Yano[CR]Tizoc (The Griffon in the Japanese version) : Hikaru Hanada[CR]Kevin Rian : You Kitazawa[CR]Grant : You Kitazawa[CR]Kain R. Heinlein : Jun Hashimoto[CR]Marky : Junko Takeuchi[CR]Narration : Paul G.R.[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (Feb. 25, 2000; "Garou - Mark of the Wolves [Model NGH-253]")[CR]Sega Dreamcast [JP] (Sep. 27, 2001; "Garou - Mark of the Wolves [Model T-3108M]")[CR]Sega Dreamcast [JP] (May 23, 2002; "Garou - Mark of the Wolves [SNK Best Buy] [Model T-47302M]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (June 30, 2005; "Garou - Mark of the Wolves [NeoGeo Online Collection Vol.1] [Model SLPS-25504]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (June 30, 2005; "Garou - Mark of the Wolves [NeoGeo Online Collection Vol.1] [Model SLPS-25509]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (June 30, 2005; "Garou - Mark of the Wolves [NeoGeo Online Collection The Best] [Model SLPS-25793]")[CR]

game.name: Goal! Goal! Goal!
game.plot: Goal! Goal! Goal! (c) 1995 Visco Corp.[CR]A soccer game with all the right ingredients, skill, flair, passion, and of course, GOALS! With 28 national teams to choose from, compete in a tournament to become the best soccer nation in the world. Get past the opening group stage and go on to a round-robin elimination stage where failure is not an option. To help you on your way, hold down the shoot button until the power bar fills up and you can do a POWERFUL SUPER SHOT![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0209[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player (3 usables)[CR][JOYSTICK] 8-way [CR]=> Offense > [A] Shoot/Special shoot [B] Pass [C] Short kick[CR]=> Defense > [A] Sliding [B] Tackle[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]This game runs on the Neo-Geo MVS and was not released on the Neo-Geo AES home console.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer : Tetsuo Akiyama[CR]Direction : Don Gabacho (Don Gabacyo)[CR]Assistance : Yasuhisa Itoi[CR]Main programmer : N. Yamaguchi[CR]Programmers : PHA, M. Taniguchi, Gogo[CR]Graphic designers : T. Matsu, H. Mawatari, Y. Nishino, Y. Kudou, H. Maehara, Chidori, S. Soeda, Hamigaki. Maru, J. Nakazawa, E-Ayasu[CR]Sound by Act Japan.[CR]

game.name: Voltage Fighter - Gowcaizer / Choujin Gakuen Gowcaizer
game.description: Voltage Fighter - Gowcaizer / Choujin Gakuen Gowcaizer
game.title_clean: Voltage Fighter - Gowcaizer / Choujin Gakuen Gowcaizer
game.plot: 超人学園ゴウカイザー (c) 1995 Technos.[CR](Choujin Gakuen Gowcaizer)[CR]An anime style fighting game that takes place in the Year 2010 in Tron City. In this city, there is a school for special students called the Belnar Institute. Isato Kaiza, the hero of the story, is a student at this school. He also possesses a stone called a Caizer stone which transforms him into a super human fighter named Gowcaizer. The story begins as a new student named Kyosuke Shigure arrives at the school seeking revenge against its president, a mysterious man named Olga, who seems to be bent on destroying the world. So it's up to Gowcaizer, Kyosuke, and their allies to stop him.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-094[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player.[CR]=> [Joystick] 8-way, [A] Quick punch, [B] Quick kick, [C] Strong punch, [D] Strong kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Literally : Superman School Gowcaizer.[CR]Choujin Gakuen Gowcaizer was released in September 1995 in Japan. It was known outside Japan as Voltage Fighter Gowcaizer.[CR]A sequel called "High Voltage 12+1" was planned. An alpha version was produced but Technos closed their doors soon after.[CR]A two part OAV anime based on the game was released in 1996. It was released on DVD in 1999 as a movie.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Starring The Voice Talents Of : Hikaru Midorikawa, Nobuyuki Hiyama, Hiderou Isikawa, Tomo Sakurai, Ryoutarou Okiayu, Yara Yuusaku, Yuuko Nagasima, Masami Oobari, Yumi Touma, Yoshiyuki Kouno, Syou Hayami[CR]Project Leader : Teruo Ichimura[CR]Director And Writer : Kengo Asai[CR]Character Designer : Masami Oobari (Studio G-1)[CR]Character Art Director : Hideki Nakazawa[CR]Title Designer : Seiji Tanda[CR]Assistant Director : Junichi Arai, Norihiro Sawada[CR]Character Action Designers and Arranges : Hiroyuki Katou, Masanori Mori, Sadayoshi Kurokawa, Syuji Wada[CR]Enemy Algorithm Staff : Hiroyuki Katou, Masanori Mori, Nobuyuki Nakane, Tatumi Saitou, Hiroshi Satou, Sadayoshi Kurokawa[CR]Programming Director : Nobuyuki Nakane[CR]Programming Crew : Toshiaki Tugane, Hiroshi Satou, Masahiro Izumi, Masanori Mori[CR]Music Composers : Chiaki Iizuka, Reiko Uehara, Kiyomi Kataoka, Kennosuke Suemura[CR]Music Data Entry And Sound Effects : Kennosuke Suemura[CR]Graphic Artwork Crew : Koji Ogata, Masamichi Katagiri, Tutomu Nakazawa, Hiroyuki Katou, Kunihiro Hirabayashi, Takuto Mori, Syouji Miyagi, Miyuki Yakushiji, Eiitirou Nakatu, Tuyoshi Namiki, Yaki Imagawa, Kensuke Nishi, Hideki Hoshiya, Koji Yamada, Satoshi Kazato, Kazumi Minagawa, Fujimi Oonishi, Karaage Kenzen, Chihiro Kushibe, Akiko Maruyama, Seiichirou Ishiguro, Big Bridge, Katuhiro Nakamura, Takahide Koizumi, Atushi Ikeda, JC Staff, Winz, Y.Y,B[CR]Special Thanks To : Studio G-1, Kengo Asai, Yukinori Umetu, Tukasa Kotobuki, Ikegami Tatuya, Kazuyuki Kurata[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (October 20, 1995) [Model NGH-094][CR]SNK Neo-Geo [US] (October 20, 1995) [Model NGH-094][CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [JP] (November 24, 1995) [Model NGCD-094][CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (July 17, 1997) [Model SLPS-00527][CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (September 14, 2011, "PSOne Classics")[CR]

game.name: Gururin
game.plot: Gururin (c) 1994 Face.[CR]A unique and challenging puzzle game from Face. 3 people in color-coordinated clothing descend from the top and you must align any 3 of the same color vertically or horizontally. During the game you do not rotate the 3 falling people, you rotate the puzzle itself.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0067[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Screen orientation : Horizontal[CR]Video resolution : 320 x 224 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 59.19 Hz[CR]Palette colors : 4096[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR]=> [A] Turns stage to left [B] Turns stage to right[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in May 1994.[CR]Gururin translates from Japanese as something like 'accomplice' or 'cohort'. Makes sense considering the noblemen fall in pairs.[CR]Gururin is Face's first game developed and released for the SNK Neo-Geo MVS hardware and was not released on the Neo-Geo AES home console.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planning / Producer : K. Iwanaga[CR]Programmers : K. Iwanaga, N. Tabata, K. Hiziya[CR]Graphic designers : M. Molohosi, K. Kumakura, M. Araki[CR]Sound : K. Sugai, A. Iwanaga[CR]Sound programmer : J. Kosakai[CR]

game.plot: Uchan Nanchan no Hono'o no Challenger - Ultra Denryu Iraira Bou (c) 1997 SNK.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0236[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Screen orientation : Horizontal[CR]Video resolution : 320 x 224 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 59.19 Hz[CR]Palette colors : 4096[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : trackball[CR]Buttons : 2[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Ultra Denryu Iraira Bou was released in August 1997 in Japan.[CR]The title translates from Japanese as 'Uchan Nanchan's Flame of the Challenger - Ultra Irritating Electric Stick'. Uchan Nanchan is a Japanese comedy team consisting of Uchimura Teruyoshi and Nanbara Kiyotaka.[CR]Based on a popular Japanese game show, called 'Dengeki Iraira Bou' literaly 'Electric Irritating Stick'.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as 'The Irritating Maze'.[CR]This game is the first that required a trackball on the Neo-Geo MVS.[CR]This game was never released on the Neo-Geo AES home console.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Developed by Saurus.[CR]Producer : N. Tanaka[CR]Directer : Yasushi Okahara[CR]Designers : Miwako Kojima, C. Yoda, Y. Hara, N. Nakagawa, S. Ishiguro[CR]Programmers : Y. Sakamoto, M. Yuuki, A. 00I[CR]Sound : Masahiko Hataya, H. Takei, H. Togashi, K. Matsueda[CR]

game.name: Janshin Densetsu - Quest of Jongmaster
game.plot: Janshin Densetsu - Quest of Jongmaster (c) 1994 Aicom.[CR]A mahjong game with Role-Playing-Game elements and selectable items.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID: NGM-048[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player (2 usables).[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in June 1994.[CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Jong God Legend'.[CR]Janshin Densetsu appears to be a complete ripoff of 1991's "Mahjong Quest" by Taito. The basic premise is the same : a girl in an RPG-style format walking along a world map and encountering enemies which are battled through mahjong matches. The enemy encounter screens have identical borders and the enemies are drawn in the same comic-anime style. Before each mahjong match, there are selectable spells that can be bought with stored MP, the screen and spells being identical in both cases. The player also has a Sword and Shield which can be activated during a match which give the player special abilities. The in-game text is virtually identical. The mahjong tiles themselves look almost exactly the same save for the backs; the mahjong game screen itself is almost exactly the same. Even upon defeating an enemy, they are turned into a scantily-clad woman as does your character when she is defeated. The only major difference between the two seems to be that "Mahjong Quest" is controlled with a mahjong control panel and Jyanshin Densetsu is controlled with the MVS Neo-Geo joystick. The next Aicom game on SNK Neo-Geo MVS is 1995's "Pulstar", shares lots of similarities with "R*Type" as well.[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD (1995)[CR]NEC PC-Engine Arcade CD (1995)[CR]

game.name: Puzzled / Joy Joy Kid (NGM-021 ~ NGH-021)
game.plot: Joy Joy Kid (c) 1990 SNK.[CR]Two cute little kids need you to help rescue their villages. Their way is blocked by rows of blocks. Destroy the rows of blocks and help them reach the head God so their villages can be saved.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-021[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player (2 usables).[CR]=> [Joystick] 8-way, [A] Turn block, [B] Use L-Ball[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Joy Joy Kid was released in November 1990 in Japan.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as Puzzled.[CR][B]Scoring[/B][CR]Each row of blocks : 100 points[CR]Finishing of each screen : 1,000 (1st set) to 10,000 (12th set)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer : Eikichi Kawasaki[CR]Planner : CHP Nakata[CR]Programmer : Nishidon (Nishido~N)[CR]Designers : N-Chyuing Born, Komura, Burio Egresias, Sankoh Chokkyu, Shimachan -PU-[CR]Sound : Jojoha Kitapy (Jojoha Kitamura)[CR]Special Thanks : Hiroshi Matsumoto, Higashi Pon (Higashi Pon MK-2)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (July 1, 1991, "Joy Joy Kid [Model NGH-021]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [US] (July 1, 1991, "Puzzled [Model NGH-021]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [JP] (September 9, 1994, "Joy Joy Kid [Model NGCD-021]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [US] (1994, "Puzzled [Model NGCD-021E]")[CR]Nintendo Wii [Virtual Console] [JP] (June 14, 2011)[CR]

game.name: Far East of Eden - Kabuki Klash / Tengai Makyou - Shin Den
game.description: Far East of Eden - Kabuki Klash / Tengai Makyou - Shin Den
game.title_clean: Far East of Eden - Kabuki Klash / Tengai Makyou - Shin Den
game.plot: Tengai Makyou SHIN DEN (c) 1995 Hudson Soft.[CR]Japanese swordplay fighting game with 8 selectable characters and 4 end-bosses and random bonus items appearing in the playfield. A notable effort that has been overlooked by the arcade fighter community.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-092[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player.[CR][Joystick] 8-way, [A] Weak Attack [B] Medium Attack [C] Weak Kick [D] Medium Kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Tengai Makyou SHIN DEN was released in June 1995 in Japan.[CR]The title od this game translates from Japanese as 'Region Beyond Heaven - The New Legend'[CR]This game is known outside Japan as 'Far East of Eden - Kabuki Klash'.[CR]Tengai Makyou SHIN DEN is Hudson's first game developed and released for the Neo-Geo MVS. This game is based in the world of the 'Far East of Eden' RPG series which has appeared on many console platforms.[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Tengai Makyou SHIN DEN - G.S.M. 1500 / PCCB-00191) on 17/11/1995.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Executive producers : Tadahiro Nakano, Hiroshi Igaro[CR]Producer : Takafumi Horio[CR]Director : Osamu Kimura[CR]System support : Mikio Ueyama[CR]Graphic designer : Torajiro Tsujino[CR]Sound director : Shigeaki Irie[CR]Sound composers : Masaaki Nishizawa, Kennosuke Suemura, Eisaku Nanbu[CR]Sound engineer : Sudou Hirokazu[CR]Sound effect : Gen[CR]Programmers : SP.R22, Ken23, Arrow[CR]Object designers : A. Ono, M. Kusanagi, S. Ootomo, Popo, H. Ando, Tamasu, Urachu[CR]Scroll designers : Kizarin, Mikiman7, Okachu, Yamame[CR]Total planner : Oyabun[CR]Project manager : Masa[CR]Examiner : Hebisan, Daichan, Marika[CR]* CAST:[CR]Manjimaru Sengoku : Kazu Ikura[CR]Ziria : Mitsuo Iwata[CR]Danjuro Kabuki : Kappei Yamaguchi[CR]Yagumo : Ai Orikasa[CR]Kinu : Azumi Inoue[CR]Tsunade : Hiroko Emori[CR]Taro Gokuraku : Shoichiro Akaboshi[CR]Orochimaru : Kaneto Shiozawa[CR]Manto Ace : Shigeru Chiba[CR]Jyashinsai, Lucifeller : Seizou Katou[CR]Special Thanks: Tomonori Matsunaga, Syuichiro Nishiya, Kenji Fukuya, Kawausosan, Shinchan, Kazu[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [JP] (Nov.1995) [Model NGCD-092][CR]* Computers :[CR]PC (2000)[CR]

game.name: Karnov's Revenge / Fighter's History Dynamite
game.plot: Karnov's Revenge (c) 1994 Data East Corp.[CR]The quest to defeat the mysterious Baron of Battlers, the mysterious "K", is on. In order to get to this grotesque gladiator, you need to fight your way through 13 with the most skilled, most deadly of all combatants in the world of physical contact. Use your powers of pulverization, psychic energy blasts, and ridiculous strength to become the explosive fighting god in FIGHTER'S HISTORY DYNAMITE!!![CR]Don't just participate in history, MAKE IT! The sequel of the first "Fighter's History", this time ported in the Neo Geo MVS Hardware. In this new version of the original game several changes and improvements were made to enhance the gameplay: now the battles are faster and more technical, with the usual friendly combo system that makes the fight so spectacular. There are also some powerful hidden moves added for most of the characters. Even the graphic was slightly enhanced, with a nice color palette and some wonderful backgrounds (especially Zazie's).[CR]The game actually suffered from the reputation to be a 'SFII clone' given by the general opinion from the first episode. Thanks to this new chapter of the saga, which was particularly appreciated by the Neo Geo fans because it is one of the rare 'SFII style' beat'em ups on the Neo Geo this changed.[CR]A really nice and classical beat'em up, still worthy to be played, especially for the real fans of the 2-D beat'em up.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-066[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 Players - 4 Buttons Per Player.[CR]=>[Joystick] 8-Way, [A] Fast Punch [B] Strong Punch [C] Fast Kick [D] Strong Kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Karnov's Revenge was released March 17, 1994. An important fact about this game is that it's the third Data East game to be manufactured on the Neo-Geo hardware.[CR]This game is known in Japan and USA as "Fighter's History Dynamite" while in Europe as Karnov's Revenge.[CR]New features and changes of the game:[CR]* The controls discard the six button system of the first episode for the typical four buttons of the Neo Geo pad. In this way, the middle punch and middle kick attack are no longer available.[CR]* New stages for every character and new background music.[CR]* The portrait of every character was retouched a bit. Especially, the portraits of FeiLin and Karnov were both redrawn.[CR]* New color schemes for the alternative suit's color of every character. However, the standard suit color of all the characters is still the same as that of the first Fighter's History episode.[CR]* New vocal samples for every characters, except for Clown, Karnov and Mizoguchi: however, for Mizoguchi new samples for the win poses and a new 'scream of defeat' was added (in the first Fighter's History, when Mizoguchi lost, she emitted the generic KO sample shared with other characters).[CR]* The in-game sprites of every character were retouched slightly in some determinate frames. [CR]* The design of Karnov was redrawn from the first episode.[CR]* Faster gameplay. [CR]* New moves and new tricks for every character.[CR]* New endings for every character. Even Clown and Karnov now have their own ending sequence.[CR]The stage of Marstorius takes place in a ring placed inside the Colosseum of Rome.[CR]The three children in the middle of the Samchay's stage are the two little brothers and sister of Samchay.[CR]The extra round against the bull named 'Ox' (see TIPS AND TRICKS section to learn more) is a retrieval to the similar bonus game in "Karate Champ" (one of the first fighting games of the history, developed by same Data East on 1984).[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Fighter's History Dynamite & Flying Power Disc - PCCB-00149) on March 18, 1994.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Karnov's Revenge introduced 'one-two attacks' to the series. Players can press a Strong attack button while connecting with a Weak attack button to chain the attacks into themselves.[CR]The following special moves aren't listed in the instruction manual. These secret moves aren't super moves, just hidden special moves with less obvious motions. Samchay, Clown, and Karnov do not have these moves. Here's a quick legend: U=Up, D=Down, B=Back, F=Forward, DF=Down/Forward, and so on. A=Button A (LP), B=Button B (HP), C=Button C (LK), D=Button D (HK). Charge=Hold listed direction for 2 or more seconds[CR]RAY[CR]Thunder Dynamite Tackle: Charge B, F, F + A or B (Initial backward charge is longer than normal)[CR]FEILIN[CR]Kakkou HakkakuSoubiKen: Charge D, DB, DF, F, UF + A or B (can also be charged with DB, but may not come out as often, slides through projectiles)[CR]RYOKO[CR]KataGuruma: F, UF, U, UB, B + A or B (perform near opponent, may be done back to forward or forward to back regardless of facing left or right, doesn't damage opponent but sets them up for juggle combos)[CR]MATLOK[CR]Loop Hurricane: Charge D, U + C and D (tap C+D to maintain spin, can move left or right)[CR]LEE[CR]MouKo Kouhazan: B, F, DB, DF + A and B (destroys projectiles)[CR]MIZOGUCHI[CR]Shotensai: B, DB, D + A, B, C and D (press all four buttons simultaneously, perform close to your opponent)[CR]JEAN[CR]Rodanto: Charge F, D, DB, B + C or D (can be charged with DF)[CR]MARSTORIUS[CR]Drill Power Slam: F, UF, U, UB, B + A or B (may be done back to forward or forward to back regardless of facing left or right)[CR]YUNGMIE[CR]Fire Kick: Tap A and C repeatedly (can then move left and right)[CR]ZAZIE[CR]Deshikakato: U, D + C or D[CR]* Beat the game without using a continue to see all the characters in chibi form grouped together during the credits. [CR]* If you beat the game without losing a single round you'll get an extra secret fight against a bull (Ox).[CR]* Weak Points: The Weak Points and the relates dizzy system remained the same of the first episode. Thus, heavy hits will flash the weak point (determinate part of the suit of the character) and after a while further hits taken will make fly away the weak point with a BOING! sound and the character will get dizzy. Here is the list of weak point for all the characters of the game...[CR]Ray : lightning (on shirt) [CR]Feilin : breastplate[CR]Ryoko : headband[CR]Matlock : headgear[CR]Lee : knees[CR]Mizoguchi : headband[CR]Jean : leg band[CR]Marstorius : leg warmers[CR]Yungmie : waistband[CR]Zazie : headband [CR]Clown : mask[CR]Karnov : necklace[CR]Ox (bull) : horns[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Fighter's History (1993, Arcade) [CR]2. Karnov's Revenge [Model NGM-066] (1994, Arcade) [CR]3. Fighter's History - Mizoguchi Kikiippatsu!! [Model SHVC-AF3J-JPN] (1995, Super Famicom)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Project Leader : Min[CR]Planners : Shintoku, Nod Suzuki[CR]Software Designers : Min, Hal, Nod Suzuki[CR]Graphic Designers : Shintoku, Mori 2, Oguri, Kazumi, Yoshinari Kaihou, Chie Kitahara, Masateru Inagaki (072Inagaki), Yuzuru Tsukahara, Hiroki Narisawa, Yasuko Kurohiji, Seiji Satoh, Gashima, H. Shibahara, Koji Tomura[CR]Sound Composers : Seiichi Hamada (Atomic), Tomoyoshi Sato (Tom), Seilah, Masaaki Iwasaka (Koremasa), Shogo[CR]Special Thanks To : Hiroaki Yoshida (Maro), Steve Miller, E. Kariya, M. Andoh, A. Taya, Ichikawa, Murata, Takatoshi Katahata[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (April 28, 1994) "Fighter's History Dynamite [Model NGH-066]" [CR]SNK Neo-Geo [US] (April 28, 1994) "Fighter's History Dynamite [Model NGH-066]" [CR]SNK Neo-Geo [EU] (April 28, 1994) "Karnov's Revenge [Model NGH-066]" [CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [US] [JP] (December 22, 1994) "Fighter's History Dynamite [Model DECD-003]" [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (July 4, 1997) "Fighter's History Dynamite [Model GS-9107]" [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (July 4, 1997) "Fighter's History Dynamite [Model GS-9153]" : with 1MB RAM Cart [CR]Zeebo [MX] [BR] (April 16, 2010)[CR]Nintendo Wii [Virtual Console] [JP] (June 8, 2010) "Fighter's History Dynamite" [CR]Nintendo Wii [Virtual Console] [US] (December 3, 2010) "Fighter's History Dynamite" [CR]Nintendo Wii [Virtual Console] [EU] (December 27, 2010) "Karnov's Revenge"[CR]

game.plot: ?? - Super Tag Battle (c) 1996 SNK.[CR](Fu'un - Super Tag Battle)[CR]2-on-2 tag team battle with 10 selectable characters with huge sprites to challenge King Leo and the powerful shaman Jyazu. Very fast-paced and fun![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-216[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player[CR]=> [Joystick] 8-way, [A] Punch, [B] Kick, [C] Attack with weapon, [D] Switch fighter[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Kizuna Encounter was released on September 20, 1996 in Japan.[CR]This title od this game translates from Japanese as 'Wind and Cloud - Super Tag Battle').[CR]The game was known outside Japan as 'Kizuna Encounter - Super Tag Battle'.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]In the Japanese version :[CR]* King Lion is named 'Kage Shishioh'.[CR]* Kim Young-Mok is named 'Kim Sue Il'.[CR]* King Leo is named 'Shin Shishioh'.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Gozu, Mezu, Raged Chung and Jyazu are the only characters who can make double jumps.[CR]* Boss Code (Play as either King Leo or Jyazu) : At the character selection screen highlight Mezu, then highlight the following characters in this order : Mezu, Kim, Rosa, Gozu, Rosa, Kim, Mezu, Gordon, Joker, Eagle, Hayate, Chung, King Lion & Gozu. Now press D. You should listen Jyazu's laugh to confirm the code, now select Gozu and press Up to reveal Jyazu or select King Lion and press Up to reveal King Leo. Note : Endings are disabled for either Jyazu or King Leo and they fight alone.[CR]* Hidden Matches : Beat Jyazu with the following teams to access an extra match : Gordon & Rosa, Hayate & Eagle, King Lion & Gozu, King Lion & Mezu. This extra match consist in a fight between your two characters (one of them is controlled by the CPU).[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Fu'un Mokushiroku - Kakutou Sousei [Model NGM-059] (1995)[CR]2. Fu'un - Super Tag Battle [Model NGM-216] (1996)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Object Designers : Rolly (R), Ponta, Pinkey, G. Ishidaman, Kattsun, Tashiboo, Sasa, Futatsu, Odachan, Akairo Megane, Yorumo O. K. Yo, Tohru, Takehiro Isaji, Kaoruru[CR]Back Designers : Muramama, Eiko, Daisuke, Hidenao JF9, Shimiji[CR]Programmers : Jaron, 0014 Take4, Bashi[CR]Music Composers : Jojoha Kitapy, Tate Norio, Mitsuo[CR]Producers : Takashi Nishiyama, Hiroshi Matsumoto, Akira[CR]Directors : Mitsuzo, Kanbei Hama, Wakama2, Suery from OBC[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Rosa : Hiroko Tsuji[CR]Gozu : Konichi Hayashi[CR]King Lion : Masaru Naka[CR]Chung Paifu : Humio Niwa[CR]Syo Hayate : Konichi Hayashi[CR]Kim Young-Mok : Yoshiaki Fujita[CR]Mezu : Konichi Hayashi[CR]Gordon Bowman : Hisanori Higashi[CR]Joker : Takeshi Kokubo[CR]Max Eagle : Kunihiko Tatsumi[CR]King Leo : John Hulaton[CR]Jyazu : Enma Ito[CR]Special Thanks : Shigeti (Shigeti Extra), Wa. Seko, Anne, NKSAYNOMKKI YHKI, Melon Special, M. Sawa, GPZ[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (November 8, 1996; "Fu'un - Super Tag Battle [Model NGH-216]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [US] (November 8, 1996; "Kizuna Encounter - Super Tag Battle [Model NGH-216]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [EU] (November 8, 1996; "Kizuna Encounter - Super Tag Battle [Model NGH-216]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (June 21, 2007; "Fu'un Super Combo [NeoGeo Online Collection Vol.8] [Model SLPS-25781]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (May 29, 2008; "Fu'un Super Combo [NeoGeo Online Collection The Best] [Model SLPS-25866]")[CR]Nintendo Wii [Virtual Console] [JP] (June 28, 2011)[CR]

game.name: The King of Fighters 2000 (NGM-2570 ~ NGH-2570)
game.plot: The King of Fighters 2000 (c) 2000 SNK.[CR]34 characters, plus the popular striker system, await to be selected to team up and defeat the mighty Zero and his incredible bladed coat![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-257[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player.[CR][JOYSTICK] 8-way, [A] Weak punch, [B] Weak kick, [C] Strong punch, [D] Strong kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in July 2000.[CR]About Ramon : This character was designed with one of Neo-Geo's major markets in mind, South America. He's a stout, masked wrestler who uses tricky body slam moves. These 3 points form the major concept behind the creation of Ramon. Ramon's designer at the time loved pro-wrestling fighting moves, and we remember him carefully studying these. The fruits of this labor crystallized themselves in the Lucha Dolore known as Ramon. With his use of 'Lucha Libre' moves and not those of traditional 'pro-wrestling', the staff team hope you can enjoy experiencing the attention to detail, intensity, and enthusiasm of Ramon's designer at that time.[CR]About Vanessa : Vanessa's entrance in KOF at the time put a stop to the parade of increasingly younger characters appearing in the game, especially the women characters who were all teenagers for the most part. This is the reason for creating the concept of a thirty-something woman who broke all the rules and overflowed with adult appeal. Her style has become the topic of many humorous comic strips. In her first appearance in the Sega Dreamcast version of KOF '99 as a Striker character, she was a bit irreverent. And in KOF 2000, she officially entered the tournament as a player character. Designers wanted to introduce her as a player character in KOF '99, but legend has it that she had to sit it out due to certain time constraints.[CR]About Lin : This character was selected out of the encyclopedic character background materials (whose volume would rival the Encyclopedia Britannica!) of the supervising planners. Lin is tied to the Flying Brigands 'HIzoku', who were introduced as a KOF side story in the NESTS Chronicles, but without the knowledge of the staff, and when Ron showed up in the ending sequence, there were some awfully surprised designers. With all the special moves and actions for this character the programmers and planners had a rough time working on this character. He brought tears to the eyes of the developers, but not for the usual reasons.[CR]About Seth : Seth was created as part of a set with Vanessa, appearing for the first time in the Sega Dreamcast version of KOF '99. His initial name was 'Dick'. The name had deep significance for his designer. Based on the strong wishes of the supervising designer, the powerful image of a big, dark, middle-aged man with a Mohawk haircut who used the arts of self-defense was decided on. Since Seth was created first, Vanessa's clothes were designed to match his. This made some people surmise things like Seth was Vanessa's husband.[CR]About Hinako Shijo : At first designers sought to create a character similar to Chie in the Japanese comic Jarinko Chie (Downtown Story) who used sumo moves. The supervising designer, however, succumbed to insistent requests to use 'a debutante', and Hinako gradually transformed into a wellborn young maiden. She was to fight barefoot, but that idea got eighty-sixed. The tape remaining on her fingers is a tiny remnant of her original concept. Since her appearance grew further and further away from that of a sumo wrestler, the names for her moves use those of actual sumo moves to preserve the essence of the sumo wrestler in her original character.[CR]About Kula Diamond : To add dimensions to the villainous NESTS organization of the NESTS Chronicles and excitement to the story, the need to create an enemy for the huge and individualistic K' arose. Manipulator of the 'Anti-K' Arts', her ice symbolizes the foil to the flames of K'. That's what Kula Diamond's all about. During production Designers elicited the opinions of newly hired female designers regarding Kula's mannerisms to "make her girlish gestures appropriately girlish" (but left the actual design work to the veteran supervising designer). Designers think we succeeded in faithfully depicting a 14-year-old girl... Asking Kula's designer about his impressions at the time, he immediately answered : "Kula had an easy delivery. She didn't give me any pain". The actual work appeared difficult, but it seems he enjoyed his work.[CR]About Candy Diamond : Candy is the robot you can see during Kula's Special Move displays, animated sequences, and as a Striker. Since Candy's not a player character she doesn't stand out like the other characters, but she does appear in the gut-wrenching episode that depicts her emotions for Kula when she's torched saving her mistress in the Kula ending of KOF 2000. If you haven't yet seen this, what're you waiting for? Hurry up and clear the game with Kula to find out![CR]About Zero : Zero is the boss of Krizalid from KOF '99, but his position in a company would be similar to that of 'division chief'. Because of his black beard and noble manner, designers are sure he's regarded as a rather scary 'division chief' in the organization. His guiltless betrayal of Krizalid speaks volumes about his true personality, in stark contrast to his dislike of traitors listed in his profile. Incidentally, The names of some of Zero's moves come from the Japanese anime 'Hokuto no Ken'.[CR]About Diana : Diana's the Amazon featured in Kula's sequences. She used to be a top executive for NESTS but is portrayed as Kula's guardian in the background story. If you compared NESTS to a company... designers often use this metaphor, but designers don't have a clue which position would fit her or Foxy. Judging by her loathing of elite managers (college boys), designers could say she's a 'big-sister section chief' who climbed the corporate ladder with extremely hard work. Working with a "fabulous babe" boss like her would be whack (but a bit scary, though)![CR]Robert's 'Ryuugeki Ken' is a knock-off of the Sonic Boom (It isn't in "The King of Fighters '99 - Millennium Battle" because of its looks, despite the charging motion).[CR]There are 2 symbolic things that tell you how the people at SNK were forseeing the end of their company. Kyo's theme is called 'Good Bye Esaka', Esaka is the avenue where the SNK building and Neo Geo Land are (Esaka means 'entrance to the hill'). The second thing is the destruction of the city that started all : South Town (Home of "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters" and "Art of Fighting" - however, note that in "Garou - Mark of The Wolves", Second South was rebuilt near South Town. Also noted is the fact that every Kyo theme before 'Tears' had 'Esaka' in it ('Esaka' in 94, 'Funky Esaka' in 95, 'Esaka?' in 96 and 'Esaka Forever' in 97).[CR]The reason for those names is that in "The King of Fighters '94", Kyo's team stage is below a bridge in the Esaka area near SNK. In "The King of Fighters '95", they fight in front of Neo Geo Land, again, in Esaka in front of the SNK building. In "The King of Fighters '96", they fight in top of a bridge also in the Esaka area. In "The King of Fighters '97" there is no Esaka stage, however, this was supposed to be the last KOF as SNK planned to move to the Hyper NeoGeo 64, it was like a glorious farewell to KOF, however, things went different. Finally, in "The King of Fighters '98 - The Slugfest", the Esaka stage appears again; they fight below a bridge in front of the Neo Geo Land.[CR]* Origin of Alternate Strikers :[CR]Another Benimaru (Benimaru) : Alternate art for Benimaru.[CR]Another K' (K') : Alternate art for K'.[CR]Another Robert (Robert) : Alternate art for Robert (inspired from the early "Art of Fighting" days).[CR]Athena (Athena) : Athena as she appeared in her first game, "Athena".[CR]Baijang (Chin) : (Not too sure, but it could be Tung Fu Rue's panda).[CR]Billy Kane (Andy) : "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters" (Andy is second banana for the good guys, Billy is second banana for the bad guys).[CR]Chizuru Kagura (Mai) : KOF, Mai's teammate in '97/'98.[CR]Chris (Whip) : KOF, part of the New Face Team.[CR]Cosplayer Kyoko (Shingo) : A girl dressing up as Kyo (in his old outfit), Kyoko is the 'feminine form' of Kyo (ie, what Christina would be to Chris) - Voice by Haruna Ikezwa.[CR]Duck King (Joe) : "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters".[CR]Duke Edwards (Ramon) : "Burning Fight" - Voice by Kong Kuwata.[CR]Eiji Kisaragi (Lin) : "Art of Fighting".[CR]Fiolina Germi (Vanessa) : "Metal Slug - Super vehicle-001".[CR]Foxy (Kula) : KOF, Kula's guardian.[CR]Gai Tendou (Takuma) : Main character in "Buriki One in Tokyo - World Grapple Tournament '99", where Ryo has a cameo - Voice by Nobuyuki Hiyama.[CR]Geese Howard (Terry) : Terry's old nemesis from "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters".[CR]Goenitz (Leona) : KOF, final boss in "The King of Fighters '96".[CR]Goro Daimon (Seth) : KOF '94-'98 (retired at the time to raise children).[CR]Kaede (Ryo) : "The Last Blade".[CR]Kang Baedal (Jhun) : Original design for Jhun - Voice by Eiji Takemoto.[CR]Kaoru Watabe (Bao) : KOF (Kaoru is an Athena fan who lost both her legs and her fan letter to Athena was what made her join the '97 tournament, Kaoru now has artificial legs, thanks to Athena) - Voice by Ayako Kawasumi.[CR]Kensou (Kensou) : Kensou as he appeared in his first game, "Psycho Soldier".[CR]Kim Dong Hwan (Chang) : "Garou - Mark of the Wolves", Kim's older son.[CR]Kim Jae Hoon (Choi) : "Garou - Mark of the Wolves", Kim's younger son.[CR]Kim Sue-Il (Kim) : "Kizuna Encounter - Super Tag Battle" - Voice by Yoshiaki Fujita.[CR]Lilly Kane (Hinako) : "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters", Billy's younger sister and Joe's girlfriend - Voice by Yumi Kakazu.[CR]Li Xiangfei (Kasumi) : "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters", Kasumi's teammate in '99.[CR]Mature/Vice (Iori) : Iori's teammates from '96/'98.[CR]Nakoruru (Yuri) : "Samurai Shodown".[CR]Rocky (Maxima) : Player 2's character from "Robo Army".[CR]Ryuji Yamazaki (Mary) : "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters", Mary's teammate in '97/'98.[CR]Shermie (Clark) : KOF, part of the New Face Team.[CR]Shishi-Ou/King Lion (King) : Main villain in "Savage Reign" - Voice by Katsuhisa Nakatsuka.[CR]Sho Kirishima (Kyo) : Original design for Kyo.[CR]Yashiro Nanakase (Ralf) : KOF, part of the New Face Team.[CR]* Maniac Striker Origins :[CR]Another Iori (Iori) : Alternate art for Iori.[CR]Cool Choi (Choi) : Alternate art for Choi.[CR]G-Mantle (Ryo) : This character is King, appears in "Art Of Figthing 2" previous her battle in history mode.[CR]Neo & Geo (Ramon) : They are not the SNK mascots :), they appear in the game "Quiz Daisousa Sen - The Last Count Down", where they are the private eyes Neo MacDonald and Geo Kentacky.[CR]Thier last names are a spoof to two Fast Food restaurant chains.[CR]Kentacky is the Japanese reading for Kentucky - Voice by Hiroyuki Arita.[CR]Rugal Bernstein (Kula) : KOF, considered to be the 'franchise boss' (much like Bison for SF).[CR]Saisyu Kusanagi (Kyo) : KOF, Kyo's father.[CR]Smart Chang (Chang) : Alternate art for Chang.[CR]Unknown (Kasumi) : "Art of Fighting", Kasumi's father (Ryuhaku Todo) - Voice by Arita Goto.[CR]Leona, Ralph and Clark are playable characters in the Foma 90x Series Mobile Phones game 'Metal Slug Survivors'.[CR]Soundtracks:[CR][JP] Aug. 23, 2000; The King of Fighters 2000 [SCDC-00035] - Scitron[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Japanese vs. USA differences :[CR]- Blood has been removed.[CR]- Mai's chest doesn't bounce.[CR]- The team specific ending musics have been replaced with one generic track.[CR]- The Ikari Team's ending has been modified. In the Japanese version, Whip raises a gun and shoots Zero.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Enable the Mid-boss, Kula : put the cursor on Whip, press Start, put the cursor on Vanessa, press Start, put the cursor on Seth, press Start, put the cursor on Maxima, press Start, put the cursor on K', press Start, put the cursor on Random, press Start, now press Up, Down. Kula appears below the Random icon in 2 secs.[CR]* Enable the Maniac Strikers : at the Striker Select Screen, highlight 'Another Striker', Press up, Left(x3), Right(x3), Down. These characters have Maniac Strikers : Chang, Choi, Iori, Kula, Kyo, Ramon and Ryo.[CR]* Todo as Special Striker : to use Todo as your stiker, select Kasumi, then do the secret striker code Up, Left(x3), Right(x3), Down. It will show a blacken version of Todo (Kasumi's father from "Art of Fighting").[CR]* Select victory pose : press a Punch or Kick button immediately after your opponent is defeated.[CR]* Alternate costume colors : highlight in order Kyo, Benimaru, K', Terry, Mary, Mai, Whip or Choi, then press C+D at the character selection screen.[CR]* Finish the game using one of these combinations to see the special endings :[CR]1) Kyo, Iori, anyone except Kula and roulette selection.[CR]2) Kula, any other characters.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. game.name: The King of Fighters 2001 (NGM-262?)
game.plot: The King of Fighters 2001 (c) 2001 Eolith.[CR]With the largest KOF lineup totaling at 40 characters, newcomers Eolith do a great job at delivering high quality fighting action along with one of the most difficult pairs of bosses in fighting game history![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-262[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player.[CR][JOYSTICK] 8-way, [A] Light punch, [B] Light kick, [C] Strong punch, [D] Strong kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in October 2001.[CR]A hack of this game is known as "Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon 2003".[CR]About Ron : the planners at the time enthusiastically came up with the idea of the Flying Brigands, the idea being to add a thrilling side story to KOF. Ron became the chief of this bunch. His first appearance came in the ending sequence for Benimaru's Team in KOF 2000. This ending sequence got first-rate reviews for its content and presentation, becoming one of the most popular episodes in the history of KOF. From KOF 2000 on, the background story became more complex on various levels, but subsequently SNK had a few problems (sniff, sniff) causing Ron's creators (the planners at the time) to go their different ways... Whenever the current staff who continue to work on KOF run into the original staff on the train to work, they are sure to grill them about Ron's background (thanks for your cooperation, by the way!). As a result of all this, he made a grand entrance as the boss characters' Striker in KOF 2001. The numerous characters who were involved with him, too, continue their exploits in the world of KOF even now. Ron is a character who uses the tricky actions from Chinese boxing and he continues work on reaching his ghoulish objective to be able to manipulate the dead. Just when he'll be able to appear as a player character is a mystery even to us...[CR]About May Lee : one reason of existence for May came from a consideration of the needs of our Korean fans. In addition to that, Eolith, a sponsor at the time, expressed their desire for a character like a 'Korean Athena'. This request asked for an 'idol-like visual fighter', or something along that line, and designers recall that it really threw us for a loop. Through trial and error, designers arrived at a character that was a long way from the original concept, but with this process May Lee, the perky tae kwon do fighter for justice, was born. Designers got her name from the person who was in charge of Eolith (Eolith Co., Ltd.) at the time.[CR]About Foxy : Rumor has it that a lot of fans think Foxy died in KOF 2001, but she's alive and well (LAUGH). Initially there were no plans for her to become a player character, but her presence was needed as the story developed and she got the go-ahead. Originally Foxy was to be a character spun off from Diana, but it seems the plan just didn't work. In the end there just wasn't enough time; the graphics were worked out with great effort, but she got the boot as a result of time constraints.[CR]About K9999 : K9999 is Eolith's homage to Tetsuo from Akira. His voice actor also did Tetsuo. For various reasons K9999 is a scary character to deal with. Of course he's based on 'you know who' and has, well, similarities that we're happy a certain 'you know who' didn't object to. If you count the similarities between 'you know who' and the other 'you know who', you'd be counting from now to St. Swithun's Day. K9999 boasts a big following of fans in Korea and Japan, but no other character has such obstacles against him appearing in KOF again.[CR]About Angel : Angel was realized through the overwhelming passion of her designer (LAUGH). You could say that there was just no stopping him. You can see his preferences in almost every aspect of her. She's a real rascal who has a lot of special moves like the 'Unchained Circle' and is one tough customer to deal with. Designers splurged on the voice for Angel in KOF 2001 and hired Mina Tominaga, a famous Japanese voice actress. Angel's designer was quite pleased with that...[CR]About Zero (The Original) : the supervising designer was dissatisfied with KOF 2000's Zero so he struggled with his disappointment and completed this character. Must have been that little mustache (LAUGH). And the character of Glaugan (King Lion) at his side also got nixed and wasn't used in KOF 2000 either. Talk about not getting your way! Along with polishing Zero, he was tortured with mission to realize his first boss character after leaving SNK that surpassed Krizalid's presence and strength.[CR]About Igniz : since all designer's sponsor had to say to us-about 100 times-about Igniz was "make him hot", "make him hot", and "make him hot", Designers made him, well, a real stud. The standards for handsome characters in fighting games for Asian fans are exacting; and there is a tendency for people here to shy away from ugly and comic characters. Designer think he serves so well as a foil, the lead character comes off all the better.[CR]Yuri's battle start pose is a knock-off of Felicia's battle start pose in "Vampire Savior - The Lord Of Vampire". Besides this, Yuri has the special attack of Gouki, the one that grabs your opponent and then the screen turns black as he gives you 30 hits in 3 seconds. This move is called the 'Yuri Chou Enbu' (means 'Yuri Super Flame Dance'). The move can only be made with the special gauge at max (with at least 1 striker - The sequence is : A, A Forward, B, C). Yuri will get Gouki's 'Messatsu' pose if you finish your opponent with it. It's a parody of Gouki's super finish splash screen (the one with the kanji 'ten' on it when he finishes his opponent with the Shun Goku Satsu).[CR]Athena, in one of her win poses, dances about and says 'Yattai!' in a very familiar way... She's parodying Chun-Li![CR]The little kid that appears in Terry Bogard's win poses is none other than a young Rock Howard from "Garou - Mark of The Wolves". Since Garou takes place in 2008, Rock is still a young kid in training during this game.[CR]Leona, Ralph and Clark are playable characters in the Foma 90x Series Mobile Phones game 'Metal Slug Survivors'.[CR]Soundtracks:[CR][JP] Dec. 19, 2001; The King of Fighters 2001 - Original Sound Trax [SCDC-00143][CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]If you set the region to Korea in the MVS test menu, the voices of all of the Korea Team change and May Lee is renamed Lee Jinju[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Choose Your Winning Pose : Press a button immediately after beating the opponent and before the 'You Win' mark appears. Each button gives a specific winning pose.[CR]* Secret ending: beat the game with an edit team, but K', Maxima, Whip, Kula, Angel and Foxy must be absent from it.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. game.name: The King of Fighters 2002 (NGM-2650 ~ NGH-2650)
game.plot: The King of Fighters 2002 - Challenge to Ultimate Battle (c) 2002 Playmore Corp.[CR]Revived 3 on 3 battles and new MAX Activation System enable you to get more and more exciting showdowns.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-265[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player.[CR][JOYSTICK] 8-way, [A] Light punch, [B] Light kick, [C] Strong punch, [D] Strong kick,[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Developed by Eolith Co., Ltd.[CR]Released in October 2002.[CR]About Kusanagi : As the NESTS Chronicles began, Kyo's school uniform changed to a white outfit but his trademark was his black school uniform (even though he's over 20!). Because of some desired the return of the old Kyo, he was inserted into the game at the last moment. In KOF 2003, KUSANAGI was treated as phantom that Chizuru produced with the power of the Mirror of the Yata. But you can't have Kyo without a school uniform. Maybe in Chizuru's mind Kyo will always be a high school student.[CR]About Orochi Yashiro : The characters commonly referred to as Shadow Yashiro, Shadow Shermie, and Shadow Chris were first formulated to balance out the Japan Team of Kyo, Benimaru, and Daimon. Needless to say, Yashiro was 'a character who used powerful body slams associated with the earth and earthquakes' in the same vein Daimon did. He's a dynamic guy who doesn't fret over tiny details, but his hobby is playing guitar in his band. The band's name has never been officially revealed, but it is known as 'C.Y.S.' He idolizes the guitarist Paul Gilbert, and has quite a detailed background story to him.[CR]About Orochi Shermie : If Yashiro offsets Daimon, Shermie is Benimaru's counterpart who ''manipulates lightning and thunderclap attacks''. But the supervising planner made sure, through trial and error, Shermie would simply not become a ''female Benimaru''. Various ideas were added to make her a new, unique character. The ''Moonless Thundercloud'' Shermie heaves up with a belch is an example of this, as is the ''Willow Whip'' move she uses to mow down opponents with flailing arms. Incidentally, these moves were called the ''Explosive Belch'' and the ''Back off, You Beasty'' moves during development.[CR]About Orochi Chris : Chris, of course, is Kyo's counterpart, 'a manipulator of flame'. At the inception of production, the plan was for Chris to use the 'Flame of Darkness (Black Flame)', but the black flames were hard to see so the designers settled for purple ones. When it came time to name Chris's arsenal of moves, we remember the director saying, 'The Dark Orochi Wave sounds good'. But other planners objected : 'It's dumb for an Orochi character to have 'Orochi Wave' as a move name. It's like saying, Call me Mr. Chris'. Regardless, the director won out.[CR]The little kid that appears in Terry Bogard's win poses is none other than a young Rock Howard from "Garou - Mark of The Wolves". Since Garou takes place in 2008, Rock is still a young kid in training during this game.[CR]KOF2002 contains pieces of music from older KOFs. Here's a complete list of themes, the teams (or individuals) they belong to and the games they were taken from :[CR]Tears (Kyo Kusanagi) - "The King of Fighters '99 - Millennium Battle" (Kyo Kusanagi's theme music).[CR]Kurikinton (Fatal Fury Team) - "Fatal Fury 2" (Terry Bogard's theme music).[CR]Beauty & The Beast (Art of Fighting Team) - "The King of Fighters 2000" (Art of Fighting Team's theme music).[CR]Jungle Bouncer (Ikari Team) - "The King of Fighters '94" (Ikari Team's theme music).[CR]Psycho Soldier (Athena Asamiya) - "Psycho Soldier" (what part of the game?).[CR]Diet (Gals Fighters Team) - "Art of Fighting 2" (Yuri Sakazaki's theme music).[CR]Arashi no Saxophone 2 (Iori Team) - "The King of Fighters '96" (Iori Team's theme music).[CR]Bloody (New Face Team) - "The King of Fighters '97" (New Face Team's theme music).[CR]KD-0079 (Hero Team) - "The King of Fighters '99 - Millennium Battle" (Hero Team's theme music).[CR]KD-0084 (2000 Team) - "The King of Fighters 2000" (Hero Team's theme music).[CR]Seoul ni Ikou (Kim) - "Fatal Fury 2" (Kim theme music).[CR]Soundtrack releases:[CR][JP] Nov. 20, 2002; The King of Fighters 2002 Original Sound Trax [SCDC-00221] - Scitron[CR]Some known hacks of this game are known as :[CR]"The King of Fighters 10th Anniversary - All Team Battle"[CR]"The King of Fighters 10th Anniversary 2005 Unique"[CR]"The King of Fighters 10th Anniversary Extra Plus"[CR]"The King of Fighters Special Edition 2004"[CR]"The King of Fighters 2002 Plus"[CR]"The King of Fighters 2002 Magic Plus"[CR]"The King of Fighters 2002 Magic Plus II"[CR]Leona, Ralph and Clark are playable characters in the Foma 90x Series Mobile Phones game 'Metal Slug Survivors'.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]If you put the game in 'Korea territory' via the MVS bios setting, all Korea Team's voices changes.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Kusanagi : at the character selection screen, highlight Kyo and press Up, Down, Right, Left, Down, Up, Left, Right.[CR]* Orochi versions of Sherimie, Chris And Yashiro : just hold down Start on them at the character selection screen. This is better than having to use some power stocks to transform in battle with the normal versions.[CR]* Choose your winning pose : to get a specific winning pose, simply press any button just after beating the opponent.[CR]* Alternate costume colors : all characters have 4 alternate costume colors (by pressing A, B, C or D).[CR]* Roulette : press and hold Start at the character select screen and push any button (Press any direction on the joystick before pushing the button to select a random team).[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. The King of Fighters '94 [Model NGM-055] (1994, Arcade)[CR]2. The King of Fighters '95 [Model NGM-084] (1995, Arcade)[CR]3. The King of Fighters '96 [Model NGM-214] (1996, Arcade)[CR]4.
