game.description: Samurai Shodown III / Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken (NGM-087)
game.title_clean: Samurai Shodown III / Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken
game.plot: Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken (c) 1995 SNK.[CR]To have no fear, to slice and die! To survive! Continuing the aesthetic tradition and high quality of the very successful series featuring 12 selectable characters to fight Zankuro, a very powerful demon samurai.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0087[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 4[CR]=> [A] Light attack with weapon, [B] Medium attack with weapon, [C] Strong attack with weapon, [D] Kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken was released in October 1995 in Japan. Literally 'Samurai Spirits - Zankuro's Matchless Sword'.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as 'Samurai Shodown III' and in Korea as "Fighters Swords". The full US name for the game is "Samurai Shodown III - Blades of Blood".[CR]Kafuin Gaira is a Buddhist monk whose weapons are giant 'mala', or Buddhist prayer beads. When Gaira wins the first round of a match, he throws a few punches and says 'Tenchu!', which means 'retribution!'. Gaira says a traditional Buddhist prayer for his fallen opponent when he wins the final round of the match. 'Namu amida butsu', Gaira's prayer, is basically 'go to heaven' or 'rest in peace'.[CR]Shizumaru Hisame is a homage to Himura Kenshin (a character from the manga 'Rurouni Kenshin').[CR]Zankuro Minazuki is a homage to Raijyuta Isurugi (another character from 'Rurouni Kenshin').[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Zankuro : This tip only works in 2-Player mode. Select Haohmaru, hold START and then go to the following characters : Genjuro, Basara, Kyoshiro, Ukyo, Rimururu, Haohmaru, Shizumaru, Nakoruru, Hanzo, Amakusa, Gaira, Galford and Shizumaru. Wait until the timer reach 03 and then press A and B.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Samurai Spirits [Model NGM-045] (1993)[CR]2. Shin Samurai Spirits - Haohmaru Jigoku Hen [Model NGM-063] (1994)[CR]3. Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken [Model NGM-087] (1995)[CR]4. Samurai Spirits - Amakusa Kourin [Model NGM-222] (1996)[CR]5. Samurai Shodown 64 (1997)[CR]6. Samurai Shodown 64 - Warrior's Rage (1998)[CR]7. Kenkaku Ibunroku Yomigaerishi Soukou no Ha - Samurai Spirits Shinshou (1999, PSX)[CR]8. Samurai Spirits Zero [Model NGM-270] (2003)[CR]9. Samurai Spirits Zero Special [Model NGM-272] (2004)[CR]10. Samurai Spirits - Tenkaichi Kenkakuden (2005)[CR]11. Samurai Shodown - Edge of Destiny (2008)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Executive producer : Eikichi Kawasaki[CR]Programmers : Abe Jaron, Oh!Butch, Magic2papa[CR]Back team : N. Azumi, Mayu K., Yoshimitsu, Yoshi-Ko, Chu, Guchi, Etsuko, Satoni, Has[CR]Special effects by 'POW team'.[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Haohmaru : Masaki Usui[CR]Nakoruru : Harumi Ikoma[CR]Rimururu : Tomo Sakurai[CR]Hanzo Hattori : Toshimitsu Arai[CR]Galford : Kazuhiro Inage (Key Inage)[CR]Kyoshiro Senryou : Monster Maetsuka[CR]Ukyo Tachibana, Tokisada Shirou Amakusa : Eiji Yano[CR]Genjuro Kibagami : Kong Kuwata[CR]Basara Kubikiri : Masahiro Nonaka[CR]Shizumaru Hisame : Miho Kaneda[CR]Gaira Kafuin : Kouji Suizu[CR]Zankuro Minazuki : Hiroyuki Arita[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (Dec. 01, 1995; "Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken [Model NGH-087]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [US] (Dec. 01, 1995; "Samurai Shodown III [Model NGH-087]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [JP] (Dec. 29, 1995; "Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken [Model NGCD-087]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [US] (Dec. 29, 1995; "Samurai Shodown III [Model NGCD-087E]")[CR]Nintendo Game Boy [JP] (Aug. 23, 1996; "Nettou Samurai Spirits - Zankuro Musouken [Model DMG-ASZJ-JPN]")[CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (Aug. 30, 1996; "Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken [Model SLPS-00350]")[CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (Nov. 08, 1996; "Samurai Spirits - Zankuro Musouken [Model T-3104G]")[CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (Nov. 08, 1996; "Samurai Spirits - Zankuro Musouken [Model T-3106G]")[CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (Mar. 20, 1997; "Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken [The Best] [Model SLPS-91024]")[CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (Aug. 06, 1998, "Samurai Spirits Best Collection [Model T-3123G]")[CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (Apr. 24, 2003; "Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken [PSone Book] [Model SLPS-91514]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (July 24, 2008 "Samurai Spirits - Rokuban Shobu [NeoGeo Online Collection Vol.12] [Model SLPS-25839]")[CR]Nintendo Wii [JP] (July 24, 2008 "Samurai Spirits - Rokuban Shobu [Model RVL-RSSJ-JPN]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (June 18, 2009 "Samurai Spirits - Rokuban Shobu [NeoGeo Online Collection The Best] [Model SLPS-25934]")[CR]

game.name: Samurai Shodown IV - Amakusa's Revenge / Samurai Spirits - Amakusa Kourin (NGM-222 ~ NGH-222)
game.description: Samurai Shodown IV - Amakusa's Revenge / Samurai Spirits - Amakusa Kourin (NGM-222 ~ NGH-222)
game.title_clean: Samurai Shodown IV - Amakusa's Revenge / Samurai Spirits - Amakusa Kourin
game.plot: Samurai Shodown IV - Amakusa's Revenge (c) 1996 SNK.[CR]The 4th installment of Japanese swordplay featuring 17 selectable characters and 1 end boss.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-0222[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 4[CR]=> [A] Light attack with weapon, [B] Medium attack with weapon, [C] Strong attack with weapon, [D] Kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Samurai Spirits - Amakusa Kourin (translates from Japanese as 'Samurai Spirits - Amakusa's Descent') was released in October 1996 in Japan.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as 'Samurai Shodown IV - Amakusa's Revenge'.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Beat the entire game in the time limit to see a picture of Wan-Fu or Sieger after the end credits. Who appears is entirely at random though.[CR]* In order to see a special win pose with the puppies, win with a double[CR]perfect using Slash Galford. Galford will say, 'Arigato!' as the puppies[CR]scamper across the screen.[CR]* I'm Not Afraid Of You! : think you are really good? Tap START 3 times quickly to make your character drop his/her sword. Now show your opponents that the most fearsome weapons are the ones you were born with! Note : a few characters are really hampered by the loss of weapon (e.g. Haohmaru, Kazuki, Sogetsu) and a few are not really affected (Nakoruru, Rimururu, Hanzo).[CR]* Sepukku (Suicide) : press Back, then move your joystick a quarter circle from forwards to down and press START to make your character kill himself/herself and lose the current round (Useless trick? Not quite since you will start the next round with a full rage gauge!).[CR]* Silly Name Trick : now this is weird! At the naming screen input 'AAA' as your name to make your character faint![CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Samurai Spirits [Model NGM-045] (1993)[CR]2. Shin Samurai Spirits - Haohmaru Jigoku Hen [Model NGM-063] (1994)[CR]3. Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken [Model NGM-087] (1995)[CR]4. Samurai Spirits - Amakusa Kourin [Model NGM-222] (1996)[CR]5. Samurai Shodown 64 (1997)[CR]6. Samurai Shodown 64 - Warrior's Rage (1998)[CR]7. Kenkaku Ibunroku Yomigaerishi Soukou no Ha - Samurai Spirits Shinshou (1999, PSX)[CR]8. Samurai Spirits Zero [Model NGM-270] (2003)[CR]9. Samurai Spirits Zero Special [Model NGM-272] (2004)[CR]10. Samurai Spirits - Tenkaichi Kenkakuden (2005)[CR]11. game.name: Samurai Shodown V / Samurai Spirits Zero (NGM-2700)
game.description: Samurai Shodown V / Samurai Spirits Zero (NGM-2700)
game.title_clean: Samurai Shodown V / Samurai Spirits Zero
game.plot: Samurai Spirits Zero (c) 2003 SNK Playmore.[CR]A 5th episode of the Samurai Shodown saga on Neo-Geo with 24 selectable characters plus Poppy (secret character) plus 3 bosses (Sankuro the mid-boss, Yumeji the sub-boss and the general Gaoh as final boss).[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-270[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way Joystick[CR]Buttons : 4[CR]=> [A] Light attack, [B] Medium attack, [C] Kick/Break defence, [D] Lie down/Forward roll/Back roll/Small jump/Dodge[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Samurai Spirits Zero was released in October 2003 in Japan. Called ZERO because its story takes place before the first Samurai Spirits episode.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as Samurai Shodown V.[CR]Parts of Shiki's personality are homages to Rei Ayanami (a character from Evangelion) and Mugen no Jyuunin. As a matter of fact, one of her winquotes was taken word-for-word from a quote in Evangelion.[CR]Rera first appeared in a Nakoruru OVA titled 'Nakoruru - Ano hito kara no okurimono'.[CR]Sankuro's name and moves (which call out his henchmen), collectively, contain all the digits from one to nine.[CR]Yumeji's attacks are all borrowed from other characters (for most of them, she morphs into the character she is borrowing the move from). Her Shin Musou Ittou-ryuu Kagerou and Shin Musou Ittou-ryuu Sasame Yuki - Sen are all borrowed from Ukyo's Bust moves in SS4 (Ukyo only has his Slash moves from SS4 in SS5). She also borrows : Charlotte's Bayonette Lunge, Genjuro's Sanren Satsu, Hanzo's Ninpou Mozu Otoshi, Haohmaru's Ougi - Kogetsu Zan, Jubei's Yagyu Shingan Tou - Souha, Kyoshiro's Choubi Jishi, Nakoruru's Annu Mutsube, Rimururu's Rupush Kamui Weison Pekoru, Ukyo's Hiken Tsubame Gaeshi, Yoshitora's Yon no Tachi - Tsubaki.[CR]The creator of the manga 'Rurouni Kenshin', Nobuhiro Watsuki, helped to make 'Yoshitora Tokugawa'. Nobuhiro Watsuki has declared many times his love for the Samurai Spirits video-games. You can find some characters in his work strictly copied from these series.[CR]Card game : In December 2006, Sabertooth Games released a Samurai Shodown V collectable card game set for it's Universal Fighting System (UFS) game.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]If you put the game in 'Japan territory' via the MVS bios setting, the story mode will be completed by little scenes of dialogs between the different characters.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Costume Color Select : everyone has four outfit colors chosen by A, B, C or D. The (D) button ones seem to be the oddest ones.[CR]* Play as Poppy : on the character select screen highlight 'Kazuki' and then move Left, Right, Left(x2), Right(x2), Left(x2), Right and then button A to select (use buttons B to D instead for different colors).[CR]* I'm Not Afraid Of You! : think you are really good? Tap Start 3 times quickly to make your character drop his/her sword. Now show your opponents that the most fearsome weapons are the ones you were born with![CR]* Secret Win Pose : if you get a Perfect win in the second round with Galford, one of Poppy's puppies will show up and run forward, only to stumble and land on it's stomach.[CR]* Pursuit Reset : pick Jubei and perform a Big Pursuit when unarmed (press Up+B+C when your opponent is down). The game will reset.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Samurai Spirits [Model NGM-045] (1993)[CR]2. Shin Samurai Spirits - Haohmaru Jigoku Hen [Model NGM-063] (1994)[CR]3. Samurai Spirits - Zankurou Musouken [Model NGM-087] (1995)[CR]4. Samurai Spirits - Amakusa Kourin [Model NGM-222] (1996)[CR]5. Samurai Shodown 64 (1997)[CR]6. Samurai Shodown 64 - Warrior's Rage (1998)[CR]7. Kenkaku Ibunroku Yomigaerishi Soukou no Ha - Samurai Spirits Shinshou (1999, PSX)[CR]8. Samurai Spirits Zero [Model NGM-270] (2003)[CR]9. Samurai Spirits Zero Special [Model NGM-272] (2004)[CR]10. Samurai Spirits - Tenkaichi Kenkakuden (2005)[CR]11. Samurai Shodown - Edge of Destiny (2008)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Developed by Yuki Enterprise.[CR]Illustrators : Dorio Takaya, Takkun, Sakuraitohru, Murasaki, Yukikage, Takahashi[CR]Character designers : Nobuhiro Watsuki, Takuro Fuse, Ponkichi, Kentaro Maruta, Gunpom, C. Takahashi, Qon, Yuichi Nakatani, Shinosuke, Kusarehada, Takayanagi K', Takaomi, Shuhei Hayashi, Kano Toyo, Tomisu, Toshirou Hara, Taisuke Satoh, Yasuhiro Nightow[CR][Marehen Breaker] : Kazuhiro Mikuma, Kengo Tanaka[CR][Tachyon] : Miyazaki-Atu[CR][Mechanic Arms] : Manabu Sakai, Yoshiki Oyabu, Toshiharu Tagami[CR]??? : Daisuke Shimada[CR]??? : Morita Kazuro, Ken, Hide. H, M. Kawamura, Nakamura Yoshihiro[CR]Music Compose : Suemura Kennosuke, Kuroiwa Haruhiko[CR]Arrange & Sound Design : Suemura Kennosuke[CR]Sound Effect : Miyazaki Seiji[CR]Sound Director : Matsuo Atsuya, Hide. H[CR]Producer : Yasuo Tanaka[CR]* Voice actors :[CR]Announcer/Narrator : Satoshi Taki[CR]Haohmaru : Masaki Usui[CR]Nakoruru : Harumi Ikoma[CR]Yoshitora Tokugawa : Hiro Yuki[CR]Mina Majikina : Satsuki Yukino[CR]Ukyo Tachibana : Eiji Yano[CR]Rimururu : Hitomi Nabatame[CR]Yunfei : Satoshi Taki[CR]Kusaregedo the demon : Go Shinomiya[CR]Genjuro Kibagami : Kong Kuwata[CR]Rera : Kyoko Hikami[CR]Kyoshiro Senryo : Monster Maetsuka[CR]Rasetsumaru : Tsuguo Nakajima (formerly Mogami)[CR]Kazuki Kazama : Atsushi Yamanishi[CR]Sogetsu Kazama : Naoki Oikawa[CR]Enja : Shintarou Ohata[CR]Suija : Ikouji Nose[CR]Hanzo Hattori : Toshimitsu Arai[CR]Galford : Mantaro Koichi[CR]Shizumaru Hisame : Miho Kaneda[CR]Jubei Yagyu : Kiyoshi Kobayashi[CR]Basara : Masahiro Nonaka[CR]Gaira Caffeine : Takeshi Watanabe[CR]Charlotte : Harumi Ikoma[CR]Tam Tam : Toshikazu Nishimura[CR]Sankuro Yorozu : Tomoyuki Shimura, [CR]Yumeji Kurokouchi : Mitsuki Saiga[CR]Gaoh Kyougoku Hinowanokami : Kenji Utsumi[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (Dec. 11, 2003; "Samurai Spirits Zero [Model NGH-270]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (July 29, 2004; "Samurai Spirits Zero [Model SLPS-25346]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (???? ??, 2005; "Samurai Spirits Zero [SNK Best Collection] [Model ????-?????]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (July 24, 2008 "Samurai Spirits - Rokuban Shobu [NeoGeo Online Collection Vol.12] [Model SLPS-25839]")[CR]Nintendo Wii [JP] (July 24, 2008 "Samurai Spirits - Rokuban Shobu [Model RVL-RSSJ-JPN]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (June 18, 2009 "Samurai Spirits - Rokuban Shobu [NeoGeo Online Collection The Best] [Model SLPS-25934]")[CR]

game.name: Savage Reign / Fu'un Mokushiroku - Kakutou Sousei
game.description: Savage Reign / Fu'un Mokushiroku - Kakutou Sousei
game.title_clean: Savage Reign / Fu'un Mokushiroku - Kakutou Sousei
game.plot: 風雲黙示録 格闘創世 (c) 1995 SNK [Shin Nihon Kikaku].[CR](Fu'un Mokushiroku - Kakutou Sousei)[CR]10 fighters, each brandishing a weapon, fight to have a crack at the Real King Leo. There are 2 planes of action to switch from and in some cases the player can use elements of the background as weapons.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID: NGM-059[CR]Players: 2[CR]Control: 8-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons: 4[CR]=> [A] Light Punch/Strong Punch, [B] Light Kick/Strong Kick, [C] Attack with weapon/Throw, [D] Change Line[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Fu'un Mokushiroku was released on April 25, 1995 in Japan. The game was known outside Japan as Savage Reign (released one month later, on May 25, 1995).[CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Wind and Cloud Apocalypse - Hand-to-Hand Fighting Genesis'). 'Mokushiroku' is Japanese for the Christian book of Revelation, also known as the Apocalypse. 'Sousei' is Japanese for 'creation of the world', or 'genesis'. 'Sousei' and 'Mokushiroku' are diametrically opposed, just like 'Genesis' and 'Apocalypse' - and used here as a metaphor for the conflict between Syo Hayate and Shishi-Oh (King Lion).[CR]'Fu'un' in the series actually refers to the fighting style of the main character, Syo Hayate.[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Fu'un Mokushiroku - Kakutou Sousei - PCCB-00181) on June 21, 1995.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]In the Japanese version :[CR]* King Lion is named Kage Shishioh.[CR]* King Leo is named Shin Shishioh.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Fu'un Mokushiroku - Kakutou Sousei [Model NGM-059] (1995)[CR]2. game.name: Super Dodge Ball / Kunio no Nekketsu Toukyuu Densetsu
game.description: Super Dodge Ball / Kunio no Nekketsu Toukyuu Densetsu
game.title_clean: Super Dodge Ball / Kunio no Nekketsu Toukyuu Densetsu
game.plot: くにおの熱血闘球伝説 (c) 1996 Technos Japan Corp.[CR](Kunio no Nekketsu Toukyuu Densetsu)[CR]The popular game of Dodge Ball is a rather unique sport in which teams of three players try to knock each other out with the help of special moves and team attacks. In this game you take control of a team and must beat all other teams (you can even recruit the other team's leader after beating them!) in order to face the current Dodge Ball champion and take the title. Features cool anime style graphics, catchy music & great sound effects, plenty of moves at your disposal and a solid challenge level. Dodge Ball anyone? :)[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-208[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 4[CR]=> [A] Shoot/Catch, [B] Pass/Dodge, [C] Jump, [D] Faint/Provoke[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Literaly 'Kunio's Hotblooded Dodgeball Legend'.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as 'Super Dodge Ball'.[CR]This game runs on the Neo-Geo MVS but was never released on the Neo-Geo AES home console.[CR]This is yet another game by Technos that features characters inspired by the River City Ransom manga. In the overhead map at the beginning of each match, all characters are drawn in a comical small body style, apparently as an homage of the famous NES games that featured the River City Ransom characters.[CR]Kunio appears in "Renegade" / "Nekketsu Kouha Kunio-Kun" as main characters.[CR]After the release of this game, Technos Japan went bankrupt (December 15, 95). Since the licenses of Kunio-Kun and Dodge-Ball had a great values in the 90's, former Technos Japan staff established a new company.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]The International versions of this game are almost identical to the Japanese version (no voice cuts as in the Magical Drop games), only the title screen is completely different & the fact that Shinji's taunt is censored outside Japan (Instead of merely shaking his fist angrily at his opponents, Shinji gives them the middle finger!).[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Characters turn VERY slowly in this game, this means that you can score free hits if you either run past them and smack them with the ball, or pass the ball to a teammate that has already been defeated![CR]* Beat the game without continuing to see a special screen after the credits with all the characters grouped together.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Super Dodge Ball (1987, ARC)[CR]2. Kunio no Dodgeball dayo Zen'in Shuugou! (1993, SFC)[CR]3. Kunio no Nekketsu Toukyuu Densetsu [Model NGM-0208] (1996, MVS)[CR]4. Super Dodge Ball Advance (2001, GBA)[CR]5. Super Dodgeball Brawlers (2008, NDS)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game designer : Scirocco[CR]Chief programmer : Makoto Satou[CR]Assistant director : Shouichi Toyoshima[CR]Character designers : Toru Tsuboya, Scirocco[CR]C.V. supervisor : T?ru Furuya[CR]Bitmap artists : Tsuyoshi Otake, Tetsuya Wahira, Toru Tsuboya, Haruyuki Watanabe, Kouji Maruta, Tadashi Maruyama[CR]Programmers : Takahiro Takenouchi, Hiroe Tsuchida, Takeshi Hosono[CR]Graphic assistants : Masamichi Katagiri, Kunihiro Hirabayashi, Takuto Mori, Koji Yamada, Hideki Hoshiya, Koji Ogata, Shun-Ichi Baba (Algo-Nicus)[CR]Sound programmer : Bob[CR]Sound composer : Ida[CR]Sound effects : Taku[CR]Sound : Fumio Suzuki, Tadashi Takatsuka[CR]Animation : Hidekazu Ohara, Takashi Ajiri (SnowLightStaff)[CR]* Character Voices :[CR]Kunio : Ryo Horikawa[CR]Riki : Masaaki Okura[CR]Sabu : Yukimasa Kishino[CR]Misuzu : Keiko Yamamoto[CR]Shinji : Hisao Egawa[CR]Kenji : Toru Furuya[CR]Miyuki : Yuka Koyama[CR]D.B.Maou : Daisuke Gouri[CR]Announcer : Manami Nakayama[CR]

game.name: Sengoku / Sengoku Denshou (NGM-017 ~ NGH-017)
game.plot: Sengoku Densyo (c) 1991 SNK [Shin Nihon Kikaku].[CR]Two warriors, endowed with spiritual gifts, fight to stop the resurrection of the Mad Shogun. Lots of very interesting enemies and beautiful scenery. The player also has the ability to morph into different fighters.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-017[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR]=> [A] Attack [B] Jump [C] Change[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Sengoku Densyo (translates from Japanese as 'Civil War Tradition') was released on February 12, 1991 in Japan.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as just Sengoku. [CR]The game includes different items which change the special attacks :[CR]* Green : When 10 green items are collected, life gauge gain 1up[CR]* Red : Samurai sword[CR]* Blue : Double sword[CR]* Purple : Holy sword[CR]* Gold : Unknown effect[CR]In level 2, there is a store called 'Boutique Athena' in the background with the original Athena logo from 1986's "Athena" by SNK.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]Hold the attack button for a couple seconds to launch a burst of energy from the player's fist.[CR]There are some samurais whose swords can be broken if the player bashes the attack button enough times. remember that this trick can be done when the player is in his normal form and bare-handed (no sword power-ups).[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Sengoku Densyo [Model NGM-017] (1991)[CR]2. Sengoku Densyo 2 [Model NGM-040] (1993)[CR]3. Sengoku 3 (2001)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer : Yanbaru[CR]Programmers : Shinchan (as 'Shinchan-SSS'), Oh!Butch[CR]Sound : Tate Norio, Toshio Shimizm (as Shimizum)[CR]Pictures : U-Rakuchou, Marohie, Mic-Senbey, Chulip-Nao, Dadamusi, Sick of[CR]Game Assistants : Dirty-H-Miyamaki, Phantom Iwata, HTMS-Sugimori[CR]Directors : Tama, Moonmin[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (July 1, 1991; "Sengoku Densyo [Model NGH-017]")[CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (Sept. 22, 1993; "Sengoku Densyo [Model SHVC-G5]")[CR]Sega Mega CD [JP] (Dec. 28, 1993; "Sengoku Densyo [Model T-24034]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [JP] (Mar. 17, 1995; "Sengoku Densyo [Model NGCD-017]")[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] May 05, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model SLUS-21724]"[CR]Sony PSP [US] May 05, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model ULUS-10338]"[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [KO] May 29, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model SLKA-25424]"[CR]Nintendo Wii [US] July 29, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model RVL-P-RNCE]"[CR]Sony PSP [EU] Oct. 17, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model ULES-01105]"[CR]Nintendo Wii [EU] Oct. 31, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model RVL-P-RJZP]"[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] Nov. 21, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model SLES-55232]"[CR]Sony PSP [JP] May. 21, 2009 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model ULJS-193]"[CR]

game.name: Sengoku 2 / Sengoku Denshou 2
game.plot: Sengoku Densyo 2 (c) 1993 SNK [Shin Nihon Kikaku].[CR]The Mad Shogun rises again, this time taking over various periods in the time stream. Now you're permanently armed with a sword and must save different eras from the wrath of the Mad Shogun![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-040[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 4[CR]=> On foot > [A] Slice [B] Sever [C] Jump [D] Change[CR]=> On a horse > [A] Forward attack [B] Rear attack[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Sengoku Densyo 2 (translates from Japanese as 'Civil War Tradition 2') was released in Febuary 1993 in Japan.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as just 'Sengoku 2'.[CR]Reviews:[CR][FR] May 1993 - Consoles + No. 20: 83/100 (AES version)[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Sengoku Densyo [Model NGM-017] (1991)[CR]2. Sengoku Densyo 2 [Model NGM-040] (1993)[CR]3. Sengoku 3 (2001)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer : Yanbaru[CR]Director : Sick Of[CR]Programmers : Shinchan (as 'Shinchan-SSSS'), Nuckey Nuckey Fuji Nuckey[CR]Graphic Designers : U-Rakuchou, M-Marohie, Mic-Senbey, Dadamushi, Ui---su Shio, Guillotine Kama[CR]Music : Tate Norio[CR]Sound effects : Yoko[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo (Apr.9, 1993; "Sengoku Densyo 2 [Model NGH-040]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD (Mar.17, 1995; "Sengoku Densyo 2 [Model NGCD-040]")[CR]

game.name: Sengoku 3 / Sengoku Densho 2001
game.plot: Sengoku 3 (c) 2001 SNK.[CR]Taking quite a different approach than the previous 2 Sengoku games, the 3rd in the series introduces 4 characters and a new chain combo system. 2 bosses, when defeated, can also be selected for battle for the final 2 stages.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0261[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Screen orientation : Horizontal[CR]Video resolution : 320 x 224 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 59.19 Hz[CR]Palette Colors : 4096[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 4[CR]=> [A] Weapon attack/Special attack 1, [B] Barehanded blast/Special attack 2, [C] Jump, [D] Projectile toss[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in October 2001.[CR]Developed by Noise Factory (their first game) for the original SNK Corp. (SNK's last official title).[CR]Sony Music Entertainment / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Sengoku Densyo 2001 Original Soundtrack - SCDC-00102) on 18/07/2001.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Okuni and Byakki : Finish China (Easy), Italy (Hard), and Japan (Hard) - This tip was given on the original game flyer.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Sengoku Densyo [Model NGM-017] (1991)[CR]2. Sengoku Densyo 2 [Model NGM-040] (1993)[CR]3. Sengoku 3 (2001)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer, planner : Keiko Ijuu[CR]Sub planners : Masahiro Maeda, Hidenari Mamoto[CR]Main programmer : Hidenari Mamoto[CR]Sub programmer : Kazuaki Ezato[CR]Character designers : Masahiro Maeda, Yosikazu Nisikawa, Nana Isiguro[CR]Background designers : Masafumi Fuji, Miyuki Okazaki[CR]Sound producer -Studio Aqua- : Toshikazu Tanaka[CR]Voice artists -Character Land- : Koreya Nannda, Yukihiro Fujimoto, Syuusuke Sada, Takahiro Araki, Sayuri Koizumi, Runnna Wasio, Tika Iwami[CR]

game.name: Shock Troopers - 2nd Squad
game.plot: Shock Troopers - 2nd Squad (c) 1998 SNK.[CR]More of an update than a full-blown sequel, Shock Troopers - 2nd Squad picks up where the first game - released a year earlier - left off. Once again, one or two players face the might of a terrorist army who are threatening to destroy the world by launching a newly developed weapon-of-mass-destruction if their wishes - to be given absolute control of the newly-founded nation of Billberk - aren't granted.[CR]Like many Neo Geo sequels, 2nd Squad doesn't particularly do anything the original didn't do. There are some improvements, however; graphics have been given a brush up and level design is a little more imaginative than that of the already impressive original.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0246[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Screen orientation : Horizontal[CR]Video resolution : 320 x 224 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 59.19 Hz[CR]Palette colors : 4096[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3 => [A] Shot attack/Close range attack, [B] Bomb attack, [C] Jump/Get in a vehicle/Get out a vehicle[CR]=> Leon > [A] Spread shot/Combat knife, [B] Power napalm[CR]=> Angel > [A] Front shot/Tear gus, [B] Wide napalm[CR]=> Lulu > [A] Wide shot/Revolver, [B] Normal bomb[CR]=> Toy > [A] Laser shot/Stan gun, [B] Sonic bomb[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Developed by Saurus.[CR]Released in October 1998.[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Shock Troopers Second Squad, Shock Troopers - PCCB-00355) on 01/1999.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]Here are the 4 characters with their codenames and statistics :[CR]* Leon (aka Lion Heart) : Speed 1 - Attack 4 - Defense 4 - Evasion 1[CR]* Angel (aka Ceramic Arms) : Speed 2 - Attack 3 - Defense 2 - Evasion 3[CR]* Lulu (aka Lightning Eyes) : Speed 4 - Attack 1 - Defense 1 - Evasion 3[CR]* Toy (aka Ice Brain) : Speed 3 - Attack 2 - Defense 3 - Evasion 2[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Shock Troopers (1997)[CR]2. Shock Troopers - 2nd Squad (1998)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Exective producer : Nobuyuki Tanaka[CR]Producer : Yasushi Okahara[CR]Exective director : Kenji Ishimoto[CR]Main planner : Mitsuki Pkc Saito[CR]Sub planner : Hotlips[CR]Chief programmer : Jo.[CR]Programmers : Levin Takasaki, Dis, Buttaku H. K[CR]Tool programmer : Hiroaki Torii[CR]Technical adviser : Yuki[CR]Chief front designer : Kurara Kiri[CR]Front designers : Masato Miyoshi, Tsuru-Chang, Michitaka Ishida, Satoshi Ishiguro, Naruhiro Kishimoto[CR]Chief back designer : Miwako Kojima[CR]Back designers : Yuko Hara, Matsumoto Kiyoshi, Kaori Nishioka, Takazumi Hirokawa[CR]Character designer : Aki[CR]Sound producer : Masahiko Hataya[CR]Music composer : Masaki Kase (World Wide Wave)[CR]

game.name: Shock Troopers (set 1)
game.plot: Shock Troopers (c) 1997 SNK.[CR]Shock Troopers pits the players against a mighty terrorist group who are holding a girl hostage, in order to force her grandfather to surrender a powerful drug which will enable the terrorists to control the minds of the grandfather's soldiers and create a huge, unstoppable army.[CR]Shock Troopers is a multi-directional scrolling shoot-em-up for one or two players that builds upon the foundations laid by Capcom's 1985 classic, "Commando (Capcom)" and also borrows heavily from Commando's sequel, '"Mercs". As well as enemy troops, players must contend with tanks, choppers and assorted military vehicles, and must also be careful to avoid any of the landmines that litter the levels. Extra weapons and health can be picked up from destroyed enemy vehicles, as well as being found in enemy supply crates. Shock Troopers is effectively three games in one as players can chose one of three different routes; each made up of different levels. The game also offers greater variety of gameplay than other of the genre; with levels having the players travel on the back of fast moving vehicles, climbing a rock face etc.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0238[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 4[CR]=> [A] Shot/Close range attack, [B] Evasive Maneuver, [C] Special attack, [D] Change player (in team battle mode only)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Developed by Saurus.[CR]Released in November 1997.[CR]This game runs on the Neo-Geo MVS but was not released on the Neo-Geo AES home console.[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Shock Troopers Second Squad, Shock Troopers - PCCB-00355) on 01/1999.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Shock Troopers (1997)[CR]2. Shock Troopers - 2nd Squad (1998)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Executive producer : Nobuyuki Tanaka[CR]Executive director : Yasushi Okahara (Yasushi Okaharo)[CR]Planner : kenji Ishimoto[CR]Object designers : Masato Miyoshi, Yoichi Sato, Kaori Ito, Hideo Akimoto, Michitaka Ishida, Narushiro Kishimoto[CR]B.G. designers : Sachiko Miyoshi, Yuri Tachikawa, Yasuhori Tsuruoka, Naoko Tanaka[CR]Programmers : Takashi Shishido, Yosuke Takasaki, Daiyoshi Sato[CR]Music composers & Sound effects : Masahiko hataya, Masaki kase[CR]* Voices :[CR]Jackal : Taiyo Ofune[CR]Milky : Reina Hayami[CR]Loki : Kinnosuke Todoroki[CR]Southern cross : Sinkichi Kaji[CR]Marie bee : Suzue Isaribi[CR]Rio : Isamu Kida[CR]Maru : Kaeru Tsuchiya[CR]Big mama : Towako Tendo[CR]Cecilia : Yuka Utsumi[CR]Commander : Meijin Takahashi[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] May 05, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model SLUS-21724]"[CR]Sony PSP [US] May 05, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model ULUS-10338]"[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [KO] May 29, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model SLKA-25424]"[CR]Nintendo Wii [US] July 29, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model RVL-P-RNCE]"[CR]Sony PSP [EU] Oct. 17, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model ULES-01105]"[CR]Nintendo Wii [EU] Oct. 31, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model RVL-P-RJZP]"[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] Nov. 21, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model SLES-55232]"[CR]Sony PSP [JP] May. 21, 2009 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model ULJS-193]"[CR]

game.name: Soccer Brawl (NGM-031)
game.plot: Soccer Brawl (c) 1992 SNK.[CR]A futuristic soccer game.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID: NGM-031[CR][SNK MVS Neo-Geo Controls][CR]2 players - 4 buttons per player (2 used)[CR]=> Attack : [A] Kick/Power shoot, [B] Pass[CR]=> Defense : [A] Sliding cut/Arm punch, [B] Heading[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in February 1992.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Produced by : Eikichi Kawasaki[CR]Front designers : Strong-Ko-Kongoh, Bomber Kanae, T. Yokoyama, Sambo Asako[CR]Back designers : M.K, S. Chinatsu[CR]Programmers : Mantaru Hantaru, From A to Z[CR]Music : Domitory Room102, Wolf.Gang Amadeus Yamada[CR]Directed by : Fire Narisuke[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo (Mar.12, 1992; "Soccer Brawl [Model NGH-031]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD (Mar.31, 1995 "Soccer Brawl [Model NGCD-031]")[CR]

game.name: Aero Fighters 2 / Sonic Wings 2
game.plot: Sonic Wings 2 (c) 1994 Video System.[CR]The first sequel to the superb vertically scrolling shoot-em-up "Sonic Wings", players once again take control of a Jet fighter aircraft and take to the skies to destroy enemy jets, boats, helicopters, gun emplacements and huge end-of-level bosses. The graphics are every bit as accomplished as those of the prequel and the game delivers a good level of challenge.[CR]The end-of-level bosses change from game-to-game; a nice touch that adds variety to an already solid game.[CR]Players can choose to play as any one of eight different fighter pilots, each of which pilots a different jet :[CR]* American F-117A Nighthawk piloted by Robo-Keaton. [CR]* American A-10 Thunderbolt II piloted by Mao Mao. [CR]* Japanese Fighter-Support X piloted by Hien. [CR]* Japanese F-15 Eagle piloted by Captain Silver. [CR]* International F-14 Tomcat piloted by Cindy and Ellen. [CR]* International YF-23 Black Widow II piloted by Spanky. [CR]* French Rafale piloted by Steve. [CR]* British Sea Harrier FRS2 piloted by Bobby.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-075[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2 [CR]=> [A] Main shot, [B] Special weapon[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Sonic Wings 2 was released in July 1994 in Japan. This game is known outside Japan as Aero Fighters 2.[CR]This represents the second game in the Sonic Wings series and the first one on the Neo-Geo MVS.[CR]The game's storyline changes according to the pilots currently selected, this applies to the endings as well. So try out different pair combinations in order to see some truly wacky endings![CR]In one part of the city in the Japan stage, you can see Red Rabbit (from "Rabio Lepus") on a sign, a poster of Mao Mao, a small sign with Mambu on it, and of course that infamous 'Heroin Magic' sign. Also, Check out the theme park in the U.S.A. stage. Among the rides, you can see the Red Rabbit, Tenukie, and Mambu.[CR]There are three last bosses in the game, but they appear randomly. The most common one is Lar, a giant black sphere with an eye. The second rarest one is Tenukii, a white sheet ghost. And the third and most difficult to get is Mambu, a giant sunfish. You can get three bad endings if you let the last bosses escape.[CR]There are a total of 47 endings in the game. Eight are for the individual character endings, twenty-eight are for the team endings, three are for the bad endings and eight for beating the 2nd loop with each character.[CR]The game forbids the initials 'SEX' on the high score table. If you try, it gets changed to 'OH!'.[CR]Soundtrack album releases :[CR][JP] Sonic Wings 2 (PCCB-00158) (16/12/94) [Pony Canyon/Scitron][CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]In the Japanese version of the game, Spanky is called Whity and Steve is called Angela.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Sonic Wings (1992, ARC)[CR]2. Sonic Wings 2 [Model NGM-075] (1994, ARC)[CR]3. Sonic Wings 3 [Model NGM-097] (1995, ARC)[CR]4. Sonic Wings Limited (1996, ARC)[CR]5. Sonic Wings Assault [Model NUS-NSAJ] (1997, N64)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Plan : Count IKuei[CR]Program : Aiz!, You-Chan[CR]Design : K. Yamamotoya, Takasu, Akira, Armored Cruiser, Oh! Kawara, Manbow Yokoyama, Eriko[CR]Sound : Soushi Hosoi (Hoso-Q), Pirowo, Norie, Tarako, Hira[CR]Assist : Mac, 840AV, Matsunami, Sisyou, K. Nakajima, T. Sakon, Masako, Hiki, Takashi Tateishi (T. Tateishi)[CR]Special Thanks: Masahiko Kimura, M. Hihara[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo Geo AES [JP] (1994) "Sonic Wings 2 [Model NGH-075]"[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD (1994)[CR]

game.name: Aero Fighters 3 / Sonic Wings 3
game.plot: Sonic Wings 3 (c) 1995 Video System.[CR]The third game in this excellent series adheres to the solid shoot-em-up template set down by its predecessors. The player takes on the role of a Jet Fighter aircraft pilot whose mission is to combat world terrorism. The object of the game is to fly from country to country and destroy all opposition around the world, before flying into outer space to combat the menace responsible for the terrorism. Each pilot has his own storyline that ties in with the game.[CR]One enemy shot destroys the player's plane and releases a special power-up that the plane may have been carrying. If the player's final ship is destroyed, all power-ups and extra bombs are released and can be collected if the player chooses the 'continue' option, or if a second player is still active. However, on the final mission in Outer Space, the player is forced to start again at the beginning of the space mission, unless 2 players are active.[CR]Sonic Wings now features an array of 10 selectable pilots :[CR]American Vought F4U Corsair piloted by Robo-Keaton. [CR]American Northrop P-61 Black Widow piloted by the Blazers. [CR]Japanese Mitsubishi A6M Zero-Sen piloted by Hien. [CR]Japanese Aichi M6A1 Seiran piloted by Mao Mao. [CR]Soviet Il-2 Stormovik piloted by Chaika and Pooshka. [CR]Soviet Polikarpov I-16 piloted by Spanky. [CR]German Dornier Do-335 Pfeil piloted by Malcolm ('Pfeil' is german for 'Arrow') [CR]German Junkers Ju-87 Stuka piloted by Kowful and River. [CR]British Westland Whirlwind piloted by Alex and Pictus. [CR]British Fairy Swordfish piloted by Cindy and Ellen. [CR]There are also 2 secret planes (see the TIPS AND TRICKS section for details) :[CR]The Aka Usagi (Red Rabbit) piloted by Kotomi. [CR]The Diabloon piloted by The Man.[CR]Planes Spec. :[CR]Vought F4U Corsair can have 3 power-ups and 5 bombs.[CR]Northrop P-61 Black Widow can have 3 power-ups and 7 bombs.[CR]Mitsubishi A6M Zero-Sen have 3 power-ups and 5 bombs.[CR]Aichi M6A1 Seiran can have 2 power-ups and 5 bombs.[CR]Il-2 Stormovik can have 2 power-ups and 7 bombs.[CR]Polikarpov I-16 can have 4 power-ups and 6 bombs.[CR]Dornier Do-335 Pfeil can have 3 power-ups and 4 bombs.[CR]Junkers Ju-87 Stuka can have 4 power-ups and 7 bombs.[CR]Westland Whirlwind can have 3 power-ups and 6 bombs.[CR]Fairy Swordfish can have 1 power-up and 7 bombs.[CR]Aka Usagi (Red Rabbit, see below) can have 2 power-ups and 4 bombs.[CR]Diabloon (see below) can have 7 power-ups and 2 bombs.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-097[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR]=> [A] Shot, [B] Special weapon[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Sonic Wings 3 was released in October 1995 in Japan.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as "Aero Fighters 3".[CR]This represent the latest game in the Sonic Wings series for the Neo-Geo MVS.[CR]Malcolm from 1993's "Ta-o Taido" makes an appearance as a pilot. His plane has a special charged shot ability that is unique to him and Spanky (by holding Fire button).[CR]The strange ship that appears at the end of each level and warps away after the boss is defeated first appeared in "Turbo Force" as a regular enemy during Stage 2.[CR]There are four random last bosses in the game, two for the Sea stage and two for the Space stage. In the Sea level, the most common one is Bagarius, a large alien submarine. The rarer one is a Giant Squid, you can't attack it and it doesn't attack you. In the Space level, the most common one is Gurabura, a UFO. And the rarer one is Soh Takeko, a mahjong piece. You can get four bad endings if you let them escape. [CR]There are a total of 23 endings in the game. Twelve are for the individual character endings, six are for the team endings, four are for the bad endings and one when you beat the 2nd loop.[CR]The game forbids the initials 'SEX' on the high score table. If you try, it gets changed to 'HEY'.[CR]Soundtrack album releases :[CR][JP] Sonic Wings 3 (PCCB-00193) (20/10/1995) [Pony Canyon/Scitron][CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]In the Japanese version of the game, Spanky is called Whity.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Choose your next stage: [CR]After beating the stage boss of level 1, 4 and 7, a checkered plane will appear. Destroy the plane's left or right wing to determine your next stage.[CR]* Play As Red Rabbit Kotomi (from "Rabio Lepus") :[CR]1) Insert your coin(s)[CR]2) Press and hold B+Start during all the following sequence. Now, at the character selection screen :[CR]3) Press Down when the timer reaches 7 and when the nose of the plane points towards you.[CR]4) Press Down when the timer reaches 5 and when the nose of the plane points towards you.[CR]5) Press Down when the timer reaches 2 and when the nose of the plane points towards you.[CR]6) Press Down when the timer reaches 0 and when the nose of the plane points towards you. Red Rabbit will appear.[CR]* Play As Diabloon (from "Turbo Force") :[CR]1) Insert your coin(s)[CR]2) Press and hold B+Start during all the following sequence. Now, at the character selection screen :[CR]3) Press Right.[CR]4) Press Down when the timer reaches 7 and when the nose of the plane points towards you.[CR]5) Press Down when the timer reaches 5 and when the nose of the plane points towards you.[CR]6) Press Down when the timer reaches 2 and when the nose of the plane points towards you.[CR]7) Press Down when the timer reaches 0 and when the nose of the plane points towards you. Diabloon will appear.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Sonic Wings (1992, ARC)[CR]2. Sonic Wings 2 [Model NGM-075] (1994, ARC)[CR]3. Sonic Wings 3 [Model NGM-097] (1995, ARC)[CR]4. Sonic Wings Limited (1996, ARC)[CR]5. game.name: Spin Master / Miracle Adventure
game.plot: Miracle Adventure (c) 1993 Data East Corp.[CR]Johnny & Tom, two treasure seekers must save their friend Mary from the evil Mad Doctor and his army of goofy-dressed henchmen, as well as gather the map pieces in order to find the biggest treasure in the world at the same time! Features hilarious cartoon-like character designs and sound effects, awesome looking giant bosses (check out the Chinese dragon!) & fast-paced platforming action![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-062[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR]=> [A] Shoot/Power Attack, [B] Jump, [C] Super Attack[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Miracle Adventure was released on December 16, 1993 in Japan.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as 'Spinmaster'.[CR]Miracle Adventure is Data East's first game developed and released for the SNK Neo-Geo MVS hardware.[CR]This game seems heavily inspired by Data East's classic game "Caveman Ninja" (the artwork style, some character's animations, as well as the weapon's power up styles are a little too similar!).[CR]The Mad Doctor also appeared as the final boss in Data East's "Tumble Pop".[CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Miracle Adventure. Tatakae Genshijin 3 - PCCB-00146) on February 18, 1994.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Mitsutoshi, Atsushi Kaneko[CR]Graphic Designers : Kazumi Enomoto, Atsushi Kaneko, Sachiko Moizumi, Yuzuru Tsukahara, Hiroki Narisawa, Kaori[CR]Sound : Oww Furukawa, Tomoyoshi Sato (Tom), Seilah[CR]Soft : K. Minegishi, Osapan, Kazumi Enomoto, Mya[CR]Special Thanks : Tohru Kikuchi, Hitomi Hashimoto, Makoto Nozu, Jirou Ishii (The J.I.R.O), Yuuko Nakagawa, Masanori Tokoro, Gorillarman, Matoba Tomomi (Tomomi. Y!!), Sapporo Satellite[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (February 18, 1994; "Miracle Adventure [Model NGH-062]")[CR]Nintendo Wii [Virtual Console] [JP] (August 3, 2010)[CR]Nintendo Wii [Virtual Console] [US] (November 22, 2010)[CR]Nintendo Wii [Virtual Console] [EU] (November 12, 2010)[CR]Nintendo Wii [Virtual Console] [AU] (November 12, 2010)[CR]Zeebo [MX] [BR] (April 16, 2010)[CR]

game.plot: Tokuten Oh 3 - Eikoue no Michi (c) 1995 SNK.[CR]Super Sidekicks is the 3rd game in the famous Super Sidekicks series of soccer games. Featuring 6 competition modes for 64 world wide teams. Utilizes Digitized Trace Animation and 3-D camera angled shots for realistic on-the-fly action graphics.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-081[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR]=> Attack > [A] Shoot/Low pass, [B] High pass, [C] Short pass[CR]=> Defense > [A] Sliding, [B] Tackle/Rough play, [C] Action player shift[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Tokuten Oh 3 was released in March 1995 in Japan.[CR]The title translates from Japanese as 'Top Scorer - Way of Glory'.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as 'Super Sidekicks 3 - The Next Glory'.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]Each team has 0, 1, 2, or 3 strengths. It stands to reason that the best team will probably have 3 strengths, unless you like an unusual combination like Attack & Defense. Here are the 9 teams that have 3 strengths : Holland, Brazil, Germany, Sweden, Argentina, Italy, France, Belgium, Denmark[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Tokuten Oh [Model NGM-052] (1992)[CR]2. game.plot: Stakes Winner - GI Kinzen Seihae no Michi (c) 1995 Saurus.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0088[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Screen orientation : Horizontal[CR]Video resolution : 320 x 224 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 59.19 Hz[CR]Palette colors : 4096[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 2[CR]=> [A] Slight acceleration, [B] Sharp acceleration[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Stakes Winner was released in September 1995 in Japan.[CR]The subtitle of the game translates from Japanese as 'Stakes Winner - Way of Joyful Success'.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as just Stakes Winner (no subtitle).[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Breeder's Cup Classic Race : Win first place in Race 5 or Race 9 to race in the Breeder's Cup Classic at Churchill Downs.[CR]* Prix De l'Arc de Triomphe Race : Win first place in Race 12 to race in Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe in Paris.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. game.name: Stakes Winner 2
game.plot: Stakes Winner 2 (c) 1996 Saurus.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : 0227[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 12 Mhz)[CR]Sound CPU : Zilog Z80 (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Yamaha YM2610 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Screen orientation : Horizontal[CR]Video resolution : 320 x 224 pixels[CR]Screen refresh : 59.19 Hz[CR]Palette colors : 4096[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR]=> [A] Slight acceleration/Decelerate, [B] Sharp acceleration, [C] Special move[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in September 1996.[CR]This game is known in Japan as 'Stakes Winner 2 - Saikyou Uma Densetsu' (translates from Japanese as 'Stakes Winner 2 - Legend of the Mightiest Horse').[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* How to unlock the endings: The game has between 16 and 18 races depending on your performance. If you get a game over and change your horse, the race count will reset. Reset the count mid game or near the end to get the extra endings. Also, the endings are slightly different depending on the gender of the horse.[CR]- Good Ending 1: Win in all the races. It doesn't matter on how many you participate in, it can be 1 out of 1 or 17 out of 17, but you need to win on every one of them.[CR]- Good Ending 2: Participate in over 8 races and don't win all of them. [CR]- Bad Ending 1: Participate in between 1 and 7 races and don't win all of them. [CR]- Bad Ending 2: Participate in just 1 race and lose it.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Stakes Winner (1995)[CR]2. Stakes Winner 2 (1996)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game designer : Hajime Yasuhara, Yas[CR]Chief programmer : Yas[CR]Programmers : Yas, Takuya Kawamura[CR]Technical adviser : Masaaki Yuuki[CR]Chief designer : Ryoumi Momota[CR]Graphics designers : Ryoumi Momota, Motohiro Toshiro, Yasunori Hayashi, Chigusa Yokoyama, Yoshinori Hayashi, Hiroaki Fujimoto, Kyoosuke Motoya, Takayuki Koyama[CR]Animation : Ryoumi Momota, Motohiro Toshiro, Chigusa Yokoyama[CR]Fonts : Ryoumi Momota[CR]Cource designers : Hajime Yasuhara, Yasunori Hayashi[CR]Title designers : Koutarou Noumura[CR]Illustlation : Miso Suzuki[CR]Music composers : Hiroyuki Takei, Shuichi Kurosawa, Hiromu Sasaki, Tsuyoshi Sasaki[CR]Sound effects & Sound programmer : Hideki Suzuki[CR]Voices : Rintarou Hamano[CR]Tuning : Hajime Yasuhara, Yas, Ryoumi Momota, Motohiro Toshiro, Takuya Kawamura, Yasunori, Hayashi, Chigusa Yokoyama, Yoshinori Hayashi, Hiroaki Fujimoto, Kyoosuke Motoya, Takayuki Koyama[CR]English version : Bob Timbello[CR]Sales promoters : Osamu Nagano, Miwa Izumi, Tomoo Yoda[CR]Producer : Takahiro Shima[CR]Executive producers : Nobuyuki Tanaka[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Saturn (1997, "Stakes Winner 2 - Saikyou Uma Densetsu")[CR]Sony PlayStation (1997)[CR]

game.name: The Super Spy (NGM-011 ~ NGH-011)
game.plot: The Super Spy (c) 1990 SNK.[CR]Infiltrate terrorist hideouts and beat up the bad guys in this gender-bending (but still good) first-person beat-em-up with RPG elements.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-011[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR]=> [A] Punch/Use weapon, [B] Kick, [C] Choose weapon[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in October 1990.[CR]A few rooms in the game feature a G-Mantle poster hanging on the wall, this character was later used as a striker character in "The King of Fighters 2000".[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Boss : Eikichi Kawasaki[CR]Programmers : Hiroshi & Tadashi, Magi2, Kura[CR]Sound composer : Masahiko Hataya (Papaya)[CR]Sound effects : Tarkun, Toshio Shimizm (as Shimizum)[CR]Producer : Konny[CR]Planner : Akira Goto[CR]Front designers : Tsukamichi Atsu, N M, UG Wada, Takeshi Kimura[CR]Scroll designers : Moriya, Take P Natsuji, Wara, Tony Oki, Kyoko T[CR]Special thanks : Sakita, Tsuzaki, Shibahara, Higashi, Koshino, Yamaguchi, Taro[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo (July 1,1991; "The Super Spy [Model NGH-011]")[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD (Sep. 9,1994; "The Super Spy [Model NGCD-011]")[CR]

game.name: SNK vs. Capcom - SVC Chaos (NGM-2690 ~ NGH-2690)
game.description: SNK vs. Capcom - SVC Chaos (NGM-2690 ~ NGH-2690)
game.plot: SVC Chaos - SNK Vs. Capcom (c) 2003 Playmore Corp.[CR]A one-on-one fighting game - the collaboration between Capcom and SNK - pits seventeen well-known SNK combatants against seventeen of Capcom's most famous game characters.[CR]'SVC Chaos' primarily utilizes the command system of the "King of Fighters" series, incorporating light/strong kicks, punches, cancels and charging attacks. Unlike its predecessor, however, "Capcom vs. SNK 2", SvC features no air guards and lacks a 'groove system', instead focusing on quicker game play and online competition.[CR]Each character is equipped with a basic three-bar system for executing 'Exceeds' (special attacks), with basic filling options attributed to strikes and damage. Additionally, the sprites from the various series received new models and some special effects were changed in the command lists (For example, the player can no longer increase the damage of the 'Zujou Sashi' used by Choi Bounge by tapping the buttons).[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-269[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way Joystick[CR]Buttons : 4[CR]=> [A] Weak punch [B] Weak kick [C] Strong punch [D] Strong kick[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in July 2003.[CR]Here are the 17 SNK characters (plus Evil Mr Karate) and their first appearance in video games :[CR]Athena Asamiya - "Athena"[CR]Choi Bounge - "The King of Fighters '94"[CR]Earthquake - "Samurai Shodown" ("Samurai Spirits" in Japan)[CR]Iori Yagami - "The King of Fighters '95"[CR]Kasumi Todoh - "Art of Fighting 3 - The Path of the Warrior" ("Ryuuko no Ken Gaiden" in Japan)[CR]Kim Kaphwan - "Fatal Fury 2" ("Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai" in Japan)[CR]Kyo Kusanagi - "The King of Fighters '94"[CR]Geese Howard - "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters" ("Garou Densetsu - Shukumei no Tatakai" in Japan)[CR]Genjyuro Kibagami - "Samurai Shodown II" ("Samurai Spirits II" in Japan)[CR]Goenitz - "The King of Fighters '96"[CR]Mai Shiranui - "Fatal Fury 2" ("Garou Densetsu 2 - Arata-Naru Tatakai" in Japan)[CR]Mars People - "Metal Slug - Super Vehicle-001"[CR]Mr Karate - "Art of Fighting 2" ("Ryuuko no Ken 2" in Japan) as Takuma Takazaki[CR]Orochi Iori - "The King of Fighters '97"[CR]Ryo Sakazaki - "Art of Fighting" ("Ryuuko no Ken" in Japan)[CR]Shiki - "Samurai Shodown 64" ("Samurai Spirits 64" in Japan)[CR]Terry Bogard - "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters" ("Garou Densetsu - Shukumei no Tatakai" in Japan)[CR]There are also 17 Capcom characters (plus Shin Akuma) and here are their first appearances:[CR]Akuma (Gouki in Japan) - "Super Street Fighter II Turbo" ("Super Street Fighter II X" in Japan)[CR]Balrog (M. Bison in Japan) - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior"[CR]Chun-Li - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior"[CR]Dan Hibiki - "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams" ("Street Fighter Zero" in Japan)[CR]Demitri - "Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors" ("Vampire - The Night Warriors" in Japan)[CR]Dhalsim - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior"[CR]Guile - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior"[CR]Hugo - "Final Fight"[CR]Ken Masters - "Street Fighter"[CR]M. Bison (Vega in Japan) - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior"[CR]Red Arremer - "Ghosts'n Goblins"[CR]Ryu - "Street Fighter"[CR]Sagat - "Street Fighter"[CR]Tessa - "Red Earth" ("Warzard" in Japan)[CR]Vega (Balrog in Japan) - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior"[CR]Violent Ken - "Street Fighter Alpha 3" ("Street Fighter Zero 3" in Japan)[CR]Zero - "Mega Man X" ("Rockman X" in Japan)[CR]The super bar is called the 'Groove Power Gauge'; a reference to "Capcom Vs. SNK 2 - Mark of the Millenium 2001".[CR]Bao (from the King of Fighters series) makes a cameo in a few of Hugo's pre-battle and win poses.[CR]The Athena that features in SVC Chaos is the original Athena character design that featured in the character's debut platform game, "Athena", instead of the usual Asimaya Athena that appears in virtually every other SNK game. Notably, a lot of her moves are now very different, and she wears noticeably less clothes due to the fact Athena loses her dress during Athena's intro. Athena's fighting moves are inspired by the manga/anime 'Saint Seiya'.[CR]The 'Sennou Ken' character is based on the psycho-controlled Ken in the SF animated movie. A lot of Mars People's moves are references to numerous UFO-based staples; Independence is a reference to the movie 'Independence Day', for example.[CR]The 'Dan Hibiki' character is once again used as a vehicle for numerous genre parodies. If you perform his super-taunt he parodies Joe Higashi and Yuri Sakazaki's taunts. Also, two of his new moves are parodies of the Kyokugen moves. In the first of these moves, Dan attempts to do one of the larger fireballs performed in one Ryo's desperation move, but it has the same range as his regular fireball. On the second move, Dan attempts to perform his own powerful punch similar to Ryo's Exceed move, but after the move charges and connects Dan grabs his arm in pain and then pretends it was nothing.[CR]While using Demitri, if you perform Midnight Bliss on Orochi Iori, Iori will turn into Miss X (from SNK Gal Fighters on the Neo Geo Pocket) as he's choking him.[CR]Suleputer released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game on November 2003.[CR]Some well-known hacks of the game include :[CR]"SVC Chaos - SNK Vs. Capcom Plus".[CR]"SVC Chaos - SNK Vs. Capcom Super Plus".[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Random Select : On the character select screen, hold Start to activate a roulette-like feature.[CR]* Play as Geese : Hold Start and press Left(x3), Down, Left, Up, Right, Up, then press a button to select.[CR]* Play as Dan : Hold Start and press Down, Left(x7), then press a button to select.[CR]* Play as Goenitz : Hold Start and press Down(x3), Right, Down, Left(x3), then press a button to select.[CR]* Play as Demitri : Hold Start and press Right(x3), Left, Up, Right, Down, Up, then press a button to select.[CR]* Play as Mars People : Hold Start and press Up, Down, Right(x3), Up, Down, Left(x2), Down, then press a button to select.[CR]* Play as Zero : Hold Start and press Up, Right(x2), Left(x2), Down, Up(x3), Right, then press a button to select.[CR]* Play as Orochi Iori : Hold Start and press Up(x3), Down, Left, Right, Down, Left, then press a button to select.[CR]* Play as Violent Ken : Hold Start and press Up(x2), Down, Left(x2), Right, Left, Up, then press a button to select.[CR]* Fight against Red Arremer :[CR]1) Finish 5 rounds with supers/specials.[CR]2) Do not lose any rounds.[CR]3) Finish off at least one character with block damage.[CR]If done correctly, your character will be transported to Hell after the fight with Shin Akuma/Shin Mr. Karate, where he/she will have to fight Red Arremer. Note : Some people (like Dan and Demitri) have alternate endings for fighting and winning in Hell.[CR]* Fight either Mars People or Zero : Don't lose any rounds, Don't win any rounds by "Time Out", win 3 rounds by using an Exceed Move.[CR]* Fight Geese Howard or Demitri Maximoff : Don't lose any rounds, Don't win any rounds by "Time Out", win 1 round by using an Exceed Move.[CR]*Fight Goenitz or Dan Hibiki : Fail to meet either of the above requirements.[CR]Also your opponent on Stage 6 determines who you will fight in Stages 7 and 8.[CR]* Fight Orochi Iori (Stage 7) and Serious Mr. Karate (Stage 8) : Stage 6 opponent is a Capcom character.[CR]* Fight Violent Ken (Stage 7) and Shin Akuma (Stage 8) : Stage 6 opponent is an SNK character.[CR]* Fight Athena : Don't lose any rounds during Stages 1 through 7, Don't win any rounds by block damage.[CR]* Mid-Bosses : your performance in Stages 1 through 3 affects who you will fight in Stage 4.[CR]* Final Bosses : your performance in Stages 1 through 7 affects if you'll fight either Athena or Red Arremer (in Stage 9) after beating Stage 8 (Shin Akuma or Serious Mr. Karate). Your performance in Stage 8 will not affect any of these conditions.[CR]* See character's true/good ending : Defeat Athena or Red Arremer in Stage 9. If you lose to Athena or Red Arremer then you cannot continue. Many characters (such as Dan and Demitri) have different endings for beating either Athena or Red Arremer.[CR]* CPU Character Patterns : before you start the game the CPU randomly picks one of the predetermined patterns of opponents. This affects stages 1 through 3 and 5 & 6. Stage 4 is the predetermined mid-boss. Here are the predetermined pattern of fighters.[CR]Pattern 1 : Kim, Dhalsim, Mai, Bison, Kyo[CR]Pattern 2 : Vega, Earthquake, Chun-Li, Choi, Ryo[CR]Pattern 3 : Shiki, Balrog, Kasumi, Sagat, Iori[CR]Pattern 4 : Guile, Genjyuro, Tessa, Kim, Ken[CR]Pattern 5 : Tessa, Sagat, Mr. Karate, Chun-Li, Ryo[CR]Pattern 6 : Chun-Li, Kasumi, Hugo, Mr. Karate, Guile[CR]Pattern 7 : Mr. Karate, Hugo, Shiki, Dhalsim, Terry[CR]Pattern 8 : Choi, Mai, Vega, Genjyuro, Akuma[CR]Pattern 9 : Kasumi, Chun-Li, Shiki, Tessa, Mai[CR]Pattern 10 : Earthquake, Vega, Akuma, Ken, Ryu[CR]Pattern 11 : Dhalsim, Hugo, Kyo, Balrog, Iori[CR]Pattern 12 : Iori, Guile, Bison, Kim, Ken[CR]Pattern 13 : Ryu, Balrog, Kim, Sagat, Ryo[CR]Pattern 14 : Terry, Choi, Earthquake, Genjyuro, Guile[CR]Pattern 15 : Kyo, Ken, Ryo, Ryu, Terry[CR]Pattern 16 : Balrog, Vega, Sagat, Bison, Akuma[CR]So let's say the CPU randomly chooses Pattern 16 (which interesting enough follows the boss pattern of Street Fighter II plus Akuma), you would fight Balrog, Vega, and Sagat in stages 1 through 3, fight the mid-boss in stage 4, fight Bison and Akuma in stages 5 through 6, and then fight Orochi Iori and Serious Mr. Karate in stages 7 through 8 (since the stage 6 opponent was a Capcom character).[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. SNK Vs. Capcom - The Match of the Millennium (1999, Neo Geo Pocket Color)[CR]2. Capcom Vs. SNK - Millennium Fight 2000 (2000)[CR]3. Capcom Vs. SNK - Millennium Fight 2000 Pro (2001)[CR]4. Capcom Vs. SNK 2 - Millionaire Fighting 2001 (2001)[CR]5. SVC Chaos - SNK Vs. Capcom [Model NGM-269] (2003)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Executive producer : Eikichi Kawasaki[CR]Producer : Toshi Kita MA2[CR]Programmers : Leather, Narutaki, Cyber Kondo, M. Asakura, Gau, Masaru, K.K[CR]Illustrator : Tatsuhiko Kanaoka (Falcoon)[CR]Special assist : K-Natsui (Nuts), Akito K.[CR]Voice announcements : Nobuyuki Hiyama[CR]* Front Designers :[CR]Mai, Ryu, Chun-li, Akuma: C.A.C. Hirakawa[CR]Chapel, Forest : Pusuke[CR]* Voice Actors : [CR]Kyo : Masahiro Nonaka[CR]Ryu : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Iori, Orochi Iori : Kunihiko Yasui[CR]Ken, Violent Ken, Choi : Monster Maetsuka[CR]Ryo, Earthquake : Masaki Usui[CR]Chun-Li : Jitukawa Mari[CR]Terry, Kim : Satoshi Hashimoto[CR]Guile : Nishikawa Takenosuke[CR]Mai : Akoya Sogi[CR]Dhalsim : Eiji Yano[CR]Kasumi : Masae Yumi[CR]Mr. Karate : Eiji Tsuda[CR]Balrog : Sounosuke Nagashiro[CR]Vega, Red Arremer : Narikinya Kiyotomi[CR]Genjyuro, Geese Howard : Kong Kuwata[CR]Sagat : Kouji Suizu[CR]Goenitz : Minami Yoshinori[CR]Akuma, Shin Akuma : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR]Athena : Ito Nozoe[CR]Hugo : Takagi Wataru[CR]Tessa : Sakura Kie[CR]Zero : Kazama Yuto[CR]Dan : Hosoi Osamu[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] (Nov. 14, 2003; "SVC Chaos - SNK Vs. game.name: Top Hunter - Roddy & Cathy (NGM-046)
game.plot: Top Hunter - Roddy & Cathy (c) 1994 SNK.[CR]An unique action platform game that feature Roddy & Cathy, 2 powerful bounty hunters that are determined to wipe out the space pirate army! Features excellent 2-D graphics & plenty of secrets to find![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the SNK "Neo-Geo MVS" hardware.[CR]Game ID : NGM-046[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 3[CR]=> [A] Punch/Arm stretch/Throw objects, [B] Jump, [C] Change planes[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in May 1994.[CR]The game borrows plenty of ideas from many of SNK's most popular fighting games at the time of its release. The two-plane stages were first used in "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters", also Roddy & Cathy feature special moves that fans of "Fatal Fury - King of Fighters" and "Art of Fighting" are sure to recognize![CR]Pony Canyon / Scitron released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Top Hunter - Shisekai Gakkyoku Zatsugidan - PCCB-00157) on July 21, 1994.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Producer : Eikichi Kawasaki[CR]Planners : Yasumi Tozono (Tozono), M. Matsuda, Y. Hashimoto[CR]Front Designers : Tatsuya Shinkai, Khozoh Nagashima, C.A.C. Yamasaki, Mikarin Nishida[CR]Back Designers : Hirolin Hajima, Munk Etoh, Kaori Kusunoki, Eri Kohjitani, Oda Nobunaga[CR]Programmers : Carib, Shochan, Imasa. F, Data Tada[CR]Sound : Yoko, Jojoha Kitapy, Shiba Pooh, Akky, Masahiko Hataya (Papaya), Toshio Shimizm (Shimizm)[CR]Designers : Nao Q., Lolie Nishioka, K. Kinoko, Mohko Hung[CR]Special Thanks : James Hove, H. Tanaka, Miyagami, STG Oyaji[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo [JP] June 24, 1994; "Top Hunter - Roddy & Cathy [Model NGH-048]"[CR]SNK Neo-Geo CD [JP] Sep. 29, 1994; "Top Hunter - Roddy & Cathy [Model NGCD-048]"[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] May 05, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model SLUS-21724]"[CR]Sony PSP [US] May 05, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model ULUS-10338]"[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [KO] May 29, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model SLKA-25424]"[CR]Nintendo Wii [US] July 29, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model RVL-P-RNCE]"[CR]Sony PSP [EU] Oct. 17, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model ULES-01105]"[CR]Nintendo Wii [EU] Oct. 31, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model RVL-P-RJZP]"[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] Nov. 21, 2008 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model SLES-55232]"[CR]Sony PSP [JP] May. 21, 2009 "SNK Arcade Classics Vol.1 [Model ULJS-193]"[CR]
